number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												It is with both sadness and joy I think back on the bankruptcy of THQ. On the one hand it meant Metro passed from competent hands into the unknown abyss, but at the same time the Homeworld franchise got hit by the defib.  Relic and Sierra both pretty much went bust after Homeworld 2. The title was sold then sold again and that was it. Stuck in economical limbo by a company that did not want to touch it with a five foot stick and rightly so, because how to tackle such a game without creating another Colonial Marines?But it was revived, by Gearbox of all people, and again hope felt lost. Perhaps it is still lost, but this remastered edition of the original masterpieces shows competence from a company mainly associated with cellshaded gore. There's some funky voiceacting in some places, and you can tell sometimes which voicerecordings are old and which are new, but never has the Mothership looked better.I know there's a lot of people who complain about broken mechanics, such as formations, but I have had no such issues. 15 hours to move through the main campaign at my own speed and not a single gamebreaking issue has surfaced. No broken combat mechanics, no broken triggers, both HW 1 and 2 formations work for me. There are some graphical highjinxes though, such as commandeered taiidani ships randomly changing colours between missions, but nothing eyesore-noteworthy was had. Whatever issues people may have with random crashes it hasn't happened to me. Homeworld was a near flawless experience when it was released, one of the absolutely best strategy games ever made. What this remastered edition brings though is so much more than just a higher available resolution and support for inherent 64-bit systems. The graphics are now current generation level. Same with the sound and the classic cinematic sequences. To get that kind of update is like turning Quake into Crysis 3. The difference IS that big. Another great addition is the remade UI, the greatest improvement over the old HW 1 system. And of course let us not forget the updated multiplayer with quite a fair amount of new mechanics to spice things up. I would say it's not just a remastered edition of the original games, but this is exactly what should be expected from a remastered edition. This is what a remastered edition of any game should actually do. It's not just a relabel of the game; it's what would be expected of an RTS title released today. But then again, this is Homeworld. It was already a real-time strategy diamond and credit to Gearbox for all the hard work that went into this. They know what they're doing. They WANT this to be every bit as good as it can be, and it shows.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												One of my favorite strategy games of ALL TIME!!This franchise and me go back a ways...i was a younger teen when Homeworld came out and I had to have it!  The game was the first of its kind. at least it was for me anyways...Unfortunately the consoles started to show their faces, and I was taken from pc to consoles.It would be years before I would buy a pc again and I bought a laptop. Good thing im a game horder, because I still had my copy of Homeworld. Got back into the game and relived soo many memories.....and soon I would stumble upon Homeworld 2...."What?" I had no idea that there was a sequel....as I said it had been years....so I magicaly found a copy online and man was this a even BETTER experiance than the original!....Alas...It would be short lived as my laptop would die, and I found myself once more sucked into the next console generation.....As fate would have it...some more years would go by and this new next gen of consoles would be emerging...and I would not be suckered by this so called "NEW NEXT GEN"...So I went and got myself a high end gaming pc....the bad news is that I would not be able to enjoy my Homeworld games any more....well not to the extent that they once did...as the game did not support higher res grapgics that are out now.But GearBox has done something special by REMASTERING a MASTERPIECE! and once again I can enjoy this amazing franchise once more!!Well done GearBox!...there was alot of bad hype that this company was recieving. But this was done right in soo many ways!Thank you,10/10!!!

												It's a remastering of two old games, so there are limits to what you can expect. Saying that the old games in question are classics so the having access to them again on new hardware was worth the cost from my point of view.The update also comes with improved graphics so the 3d models now look great at 2560x1400 on a 27" monitor, much in the same way that I remember how goood the originals looked at 1280x1024 on a 21" monitor. If you have played the original games (and can still remember back that far) you are looking at around 30 hours of game play to complete the included missions. beyond that there are PvC skirmish modes and a PvP system in beta.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												Just finished the Remastered Homeworld and it was a great experience.However there is some things to be aware of:There is only the one dificulty level so when you have finished the campaign I don't see much reason to replay it.The fleet is preserved during the campaign this means that some of the later levels become too easy beacuse your fleet is too good or the level is impossible because your fleet is too small...I had to restart the campaign because I just barely  made one level to be totally crushed in the next. However after the restart I steamrolled the later leves.The space view sometimes turns black for unknown reasons and it's impossible to do anything, if this happens save and reload and the view is back.If MSI Afterburner is running there are lots of graphical glitches so don't.The game crashed once and lvl 6 didn't have any objectives once so it was impossible to finish the map (worked after restart of map) but other than that I think the game was pretty solid.Oh and the Junkyard dog stopped stealing my ships after a while I don't know if this was a glitch or by design.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Updated:  Make sure to read the bottom edit.The countless hours I spent on this series as a youngster were some of my fondest memories of gaming. I completed the campaign for Homeworld at least 3 times, HW2 twice, and Cataclysm (somewhat non-canon, but still good) a few times as well. I've only reached the fifth mission in this HW1 Remastered campaign, but it appears Gearbox did the series proud. It's beautiful without compromising the original art, the updated interface is mostly an improvement (I'm not crazy about the different hotkeys) and the sound updates are amazing. There are nuances to the sounds that I never picked up in all the time I used to play the game.One change that had me absolutely giddy is that it's now (much more) possible for salvage frigates to capture Turanic Raider ships. I always wanted a fleet of Missile Corvettes, and now it's possible to nab them all!Overall, I'm blown away by this remaster. I'm overjoyed at how well it's done. If you never played the Homeworld games and you're an RTS or space fan, do yourself a favor and play this game, now.Edit: There are some serious issues with the game that I hope will be fixed soon. These are:1) Harvesting resources in HW1R is buggy, and requires babysitting and constantly reassigning the harvesters. They will stop harvesting, even when there are additional resources 30 seconds away.2) Strike Craft Formations and Tactics are useless and broken: Moving HW1 content to the HW2 engine clearly broke these, and they are critical to making strike craft useful. As they are right now, you will constantly lose all your strike craft due to the unit AI's inability to utilize tactics and formations. It forces you to just boat captured Assault Frigate swarms and other Frigate/Capital ships instead. This is a major and disappointing issue, and possibly the worst of the list.3) The projectile system was dropped in favor of the "dice roll" system of HW2. This was one of the coolest parts of HW1, and was amazing to watch in action. Projectiles were actually fired and could hit targets on the other side of the target by accident. This led to strike craft being much more useful, as they could dodge rounds coming towards them, allowing them to overwhelm large capital ships. Now, Heavy Cruisers, Destroyers and Assault Frigates wipe out dozens of fighters without breaking a sweat. The best anti-everything weapon is just a mass of capital ships, in all circumstances. Forget attack bombers and defenders. The only reason to builds scouts and interceptors is as a cheap meat shield or disposable scouting element.4) Time to Kill is INSANE. INSANE. Take two heavy cruisers or destroyers, and have them start shooting at each other. They die in like 30 seconds. It used to take twice that long, turning capital ship fights into epic slugging matches. Now, it's all just one giant, stupid deathball.5) Scaled difficulty is broken: Just collect a few dozen ships, and by mission 10, you'll see what I mean. If you're familiar with the original HW, you'll see that they have more than quadrupled the number of enemy ships guarding the ghost ship. It's hilarious and game breaking.I really hope they fix these issues, as HW is one of my favorite franchises, ever. It pains me to say this, but HW1R is not worth playing until most of the bugs get fixed. I haven't played HW2R enough to see, but I'm sure it's fine as it's in the same engine. If you want to play HW1, stick to the classic version. I pray it doesn't have the same issues.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Probably one of the best, if not THE best HD remaster of a game to date. Sure, games have advanced a bit since, but this game is a classic, and is in all aspects a work of art. Both sight and sound. The remaster does several things.1 - It makes the game something you can get without a cdrom. 2 - It vastly improves the games models, textures, and effects (it was visually stunning in its day, and now its even more so). 3 - It resampled all the games audio to be much more high quality4 - Vastly improved (and scaleable) UI.5 - Both homeworld and homeworld 2 in one package6 - New multiplayer functionality.For me, it was worth it just to be able to play through the 2 games stories again, on a new high end system, and have the game look and perform amazingly. This game is an experience, one that hasnt really been duplicated since it was released. New game devs could learn a lot from it, but in the mean time, im glad to get to play this series again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Absolutely spectacular remake of the beloved HW franchise.  The graphics are amazing, and the changes they made to both HW1 and HW2 are much needed (for example, getting rid of the fuel requirement in HW1). These games are STILL the best RTS ever made, and they really shine here.  If you've never played Homeworld, you've never experienced the best the RTS genre has to offer.  Homeworld has been my all time favorite game since its release, so I am very critical of anything Gearbox is doing with this franchise.  I'm happy to say that the remastering was done with a TON of care and love, and the bugs I've seen are very few and far between-a relief in this day of publishers releasing so many unfinished games.  It can only get better from here.  Way to go Gearbox, you've successfully brought back Homeworld!  Now make Homeworld 3 so all my dreams can come true!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												This game is everything a Homeworld faithful could have hoped for! After a decade, it is so refreshing to play one of the greatest games ever made with a fresh coat of paint. The story is still as evocative as ever (better than any trash AAA game currently out there,) the strategy is as complex as you wish to make it, and the graphics...the originals still look good, but holy cow the remasters are gorgeous! The dialogue was wonderfully redone, staying true to the originals whilst adding some depth and emotion. The game isn't a breeze to beat, but it's not a 4X either. It's just enough challenge to make you claw back for more!The only potential things I would have done differently:Bring squadrons to the original, it's tough to micromanage so many ships with only 10 groupsAdd more ship types (such as from the complex mods) to give greater depth, especially in HW2Having the 4 races be playable is great, but it'd be nice to have a mode with playable Keepers and Progenitors tooThere is embedded mod support in the main menu so I imagine once modders get their eager hands on the code and start releasing stuff it'll be a lot easier to incorporate them into the game. This is great, since I was never able to make the Complex mods work on my Windows 8 machine.Looking forward to several more years of this game!

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												A few things that I have observed about Homeworld 1 remastered so far (Just finished mission 4)-No fuel system, making strike craft more useful for prolonged missions without support-Repairs of strike craft and Capital Ships seem to be free (Vanilla they were not)-Research now costs RU (In vanilla they were not)-Large enough ships now leave debris when destroyed (Turanic Carrier), which can now be salvaged for RU by Harvesters and Salvage Corvettes.-You can still capture ships, expect an all star-cast of Turanic, Taidaan and Kadeshi Capitals fighting for your cause (Just not the two Assault frigates from Mission 3, nor the Turanic Carrier)-Ships have problems staying in formation.-No seperate screen for research and ship building, meaning you have better situational awareness than you did in the Vanilla Game-I was hoping for a patrol control, but you only have a waypoint mode that cannot be used to create a permanent patrolThere may be more changes that I haven't noticed yet but those are the highlights. Can't wait till someone creates the inevitable Battlestar, Star Citizen, Star Trek, Star War, Babylon 5 mods for this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												HOMEWORLD REMASTERED COLLECTION REVIEW (Reccomended-Strategist2_0)Player Base: First Time Homeworld Player. Hence, my reviews are based on initial first impression of the game (particularly Homeworld Remastered. Updated reviews will be added below)Homeworld Remastered (Updated-26/02/2015)<Impression> This game is straight out beautiful, with amazing choice of soundtracks that helps you fully immerse in the game and also has that rare ability to keep you investing more and more in the lore of the game. I particulally appreciate the developer's effort in adding a reworked, complete, and simple tutorial for such a challenging RTS game such as this. The cutscene dialogues does seems to be abit bland at times as the characters in the game apart from the mothership speaks in a rather unconvincing voice, with minimal expression though this does not significantly affect the gameplay nor the total enjoyability of this game. After playing the original Homeworld, I discovered that it seems to me that the dialogues are ported to the remastered edition and as such the game is not at fault here though I do wish that it could be reworked as well. So far, it works perfectly fine on my PC with no bugs encountered just yet as I am aware that certain people are having issues with the game. Issues thread below:http://steamcommunity.com/app/244160/discussions/0/617328967243529430/Pros: + BEAUTIFUL graphics+ Amazing soundtrack+ Addictive gameplay+ Great and epic story+ Purposeful level designCons:- The in-game dialogue could use an upgrade=============================================================================Homeworld Original (Updated-26/02/2015)<Impression> Playing the Original makes me appreciate the remastered edition as much as I have respect for the original. Though the graphics are not particularly amazing like the remastered edition, it is well ahead of its time then and was a marvel to watch. Gameplay is butter smooth and there is no bug encountered just yet. Since this is the original, it goes without saying that the resolution could only be maxed to 1024x640 (16 or 32 bit) and not beyond. For newcomers such as myself, I recommend that you finished the remastered edition first to develop interest before playing the original. I would also like to express my gratitude for having this game included together by the developer as it kept me invested in the game and its a blast to play with.Pros: + Epic Story and lore+ Great gameplay+ Has great valueCons:- None so far=============================================================================*MORE REVIEWS TO COME*

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Oh my god.  Homeworld's back.  I never thought I'd see this day.  I don't know how many hours I put into the originals.So far, not many bugs on release other than a couple crashes.  If you crash, lower the texture quality a notch.  Even at 2048 texture size, it's beautifulTo top it off, this is NOT one of those games that looks better through nostalgia glasses.  Between all the engine improvements, HD textures, etc, it's BETTER.I remember playing HW1 when I was a kid and getting destroyed.  15 years later, with an adult mind, it feels like a different game.  I know how to manage resources better, I know the strengths and weaknesses of ships better, and try to organize my fleet instead of throwing units against the enemy hoping to get a kill.EVEN IF YOU DON'T LIKE RTS, GIVE THIS GAME A TRY.  It looks like another overcomplicated space RTS, but it's really not.  It's complicated in its own ways, but very easy to learn the basic tactics and rock-paper-scissor mechanics between all the different ships.This isn't like other RTSs.  It's very easy to pick up and play, hard to master against real players, but the selling point is the beautiful campaigns of HW1 and 2.  Not to mention the massive battles, with fighters zipping everywhere with their glowing contrails, and massive capital ships hammering at each other with cannons and ion beems.Good lord, it's been a long time.  It's more beautiful than I remember; with the Remastered engine, it's more than just a polished up HW2 engine.  Check out any comparison videos.This game has gotten *BETTER* with time.  How many series/remakes can say that?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Just to start i must stat that im a huge fan of the homeworld series (owning all 3 big box editions of the original games in all their glory) when i found out about this i preorderd the special edition.To start the game is beautiful with new stunning skins, great new sound effects, cleaned up audio for the voice acting and wonderful draw cutscenes, not to mention the easier to use UI of homeworld 2 that makes homeworld 1 singleplayer that much easier and fun to play. These games hold their own on gameplay alone (dont believe me?, try the classic editions bundled into the collection!) but the remaster really does make the places you play in that much more special. The multiplayer (against bots for the moment) is also fun, being able to use any of the 4 major races across both games is really intreasting and gives alot more replayability.Its not all good news tho as this games does have bugs, so far iv noticed certain ships clipping through each other, ships not dissappearing after hyperdrive, the overview map not working at times, and crashes to name a few. However i still recommend this game as it is, with gearbox supporting modding for this game and a huge modding community already around, as well as possibility of (decent!) DLC and bug fixes, its a bright intergalactic future for Homeworld.

												For years I have loved this game and used tons of mods. So many good memories of epic LAN parties. Multiplayer was hard without gamespy, but we made do with tunngle and gameranger... still.. multiplayer works so smoothly now! Granted, is there a rank system, friend interactions, stat trackers and such in the game? No. But I am sure that will come as they finishing balancing things and move the multiplayer out of BETA. Overall, I have 0 complaints about the remake. Just praise... and praise... and praise. Good job Gearbox! You know how to win the hearts of players!

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Favorite game of all time. A few bugs to start of with but withing an hour they had a new update out to take care of some of them.Homeworld RM is amazing, the high detail on the ships from rotating canons to the laser lights reflected across the ships and objects in space, to the remastered sound, which is amazing if you turn it all the way up.The 3D evironment in which you can move ships is so amazing and just like  I remember it. Overall the best game out. Well done Gearbox.To everyone complaining about the little bugs. It was know beforehand that there would be bugs. Gearbox wanted people to play and find all the bugs so that they could fix them. If you watch all the videos on the developers, you can see that they really are keen to keep this game going and fix all the bugs, so get off there backs and give them time to fix things. Rewriting code and troubleshooting is not easy most of the time. For the amount of time they\ve spent on this, which is surpising little. It's amazing!

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I own all homeworld titles, I still play them including some of the mods every now and then.  I simply love the game.  Started playing this and it's the best game reborn.  This is not a 100% clone.  There are new elements in the game if my memory serves me right.  The missions and the storyline are more or less the same so far, cinematics are new.  The sountrack is the same, which is actually a very good thing.  The soundtrack alone deserves a medal.  Visuals are extremely updated.  Spoiler alert:  I don't remember some of the ships that Bentusi trades nor do I remember that Bentusi EVER gave me an option to buy tech in the originals.  I'm not far along with the "Remastered" and already see differences to the Classics.Homeworld title is one of the most aclaimed in the industry.  16 years later there are still thousands asking for the next installment.  There are multiple forums and blogs dedicated to HW still in full force and active.   If you are new to the Homeworld and love strategy, you simply have to play it!  If you have played it without enjoyment, this won't skew your view and may seem repetitive, but if you loved the Classics, you'll appreciate the "Remastered" in its full glory.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												Classical Homeworld with a modern take on the graphics looks very impressive.However to point out, this is a very new title (at the time of the review), so it has some small issues.The biggest issue I have is the inability to PAUSE multiplayer matches, are times I have to go do something else, and I need to pause the game.Aside from that one fact, singleplayer games for what they have remastered look amazing, but still again at a cost.There are issues were the original game (Homeworld) could do more game mechanics wise.I suppose the fact that they're using a homeworld 2 engine has something to do with these issues so far.I would also like to see Cataclysm in this "collection" as its not much of a collection without it.Nearly forgot, the Remastered Collection for me atleast, runs better then the originals.Steam Workshop also provides a very nice way to install your favorite mods too.Overall I feel it was worth the time to get this particular title.

												A faithful remaster of my favorite space strategy game of all time.  Possibly my favorite game.  The graphics updates are stunning, and Gearbox has been faithful to patch to improve balancing and fix bugs.  The voice acting is so much better than most strategy games, which is a pet peeve of mine.  There are a few good mods out there too.   If you want a fair challenge, love space strategy or beautiful spaceship design, love the original, or like to watch ships blow up and go boom, then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												When i saw this series for the first time, it caught my eye. why? it was the sheer beauty of it. and im not even talking about the remastered version, or the graphics of the games, remastered or not. it was the concept, the story, and the level of pure thought that goes into every moment of gameplay. The story is a classic tale of an odyssey across the stars to find your one true home, and along the way you meet friends, and monsters. You find those who have simply strayed from their paths, and those who want nothing more to see you burn. you must use your 3 dimensional battlefield to your advantage, and plot every move, for one slip up can cost you your fleet. The game is very well put together overall, and the originals are well preserved, the remastered ones however are not entirely true to the classic versions. In some instances you face more enemies than in the original, or Certain events do not occur at the right time or in the right spot. these are minor changes at best, but a sound strategy that worked in the classics, may not work in the remastered ones. Older fans will not be dissapointed, and new fans will hardly notice the difference. Despite these gripes i have to say it is still one of the best strategy games i have ever played, and certainly my favorite.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												It is with both sadness and joy I think back on the bankruptcy of THQ. On the one hand it meant Metro passed from competent hands into the unknown abyss, but at the same time the Homeworld franchise got hit by the defib.  Relic and Sierra both pretty much went bust after Homeworld 2. The title was sold then sold again and that was it. Stuck in economical limbo by a company that did not want to touch it with a five foot stick and rightly so, because how to tackle such a game without creating another Colonial Marines?But it was revived, by Gearbox of all people, and again hope felt lost. Perhaps it is still lost, but this remastered edition of the original masterpieces shows competence from a company mainly associated with cellshaded gore. There's some funky voiceacting in some places, and you can tell sometimes which voicerecordings are old and which are new, but never has the Mothership looked better.I know there's a lot of people who complain about broken mechanics, such as formations, but I have had no such issues. 15 hours to move through the main campaign at my own speed and not a single gamebreaking issue has surfaced. No broken combat mechanics, no broken triggers, both HW 1 and 2 formations work for me. There are some graphical highjinxes though, such as commandeered taiidani ships randomly changing colours between missions, but nothing eyesore-noteworthy was had. Whatever issues people may have with random crashes it hasn't happened to me. Homeworld was a near flawless experience when it was released, one of the absolutely best strategy games ever made. What this remastered edition brings though is so much more than just a higher available resolution and support for inherent 64-bit systems. The graphics are now current generation level. Same with the sound and the classic cinematic sequences. To get that kind of update is like turning Quake into Crysis 3. The difference IS that big. Another great addition is the remade UI, the greatest improvement over the old HW 1 system. And of course let us not forget the updated multiplayer with quite a fair amount of new mechanics to spice things up. I would say it's not just a remastered edition of the original games, but this is exactly what should be expected from a remastered edition. This is what a remastered edition of any game should actually do. It's not just a relabel of the game; it's what would be expected of an RTS title released today. But then again, this is Homeworld. It was already a real-time strategy diamond and credit to Gearbox for all the hard work that went into this. They know what they're doing. They WANT this to be every bit as good as it can be, and it shows.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												To put it simply - Homeworld literally revolutionized the RTS genre when it was first released over 15 years ago. I bought the original game and throughout the years, it was always a deep regret that this great game was not available on Steam for everyone else to discover... until now! This remastered version is not just putting the original game on the Steam store - every part of the game has been improved and updated, surpassing all expectations for such a classic reborn. This digital collection is a great opportunity to experience what made Homeworld such an enduring game. The amazing fanbase which has kept this game alive all these years finally prompted the original developers to update and release it on Steam. If you are a fan of the Star Wars movies or gigantic space battles with epic scenery, this is definitely something that you should check out. Homeworld is quite different and special compared to other RTS games - it has an original outlook on space combat with a game engine capitalizing on the beauty of combat in space, which has never been as successfully captured in any other games. The game is so beautiful that you could make movies from the gameplay footage if you wanted - in fact, there are several fan-made movies out there with Star Wars or Battlestar Galactica mods, simulating the original look of the various ships in their respective franchise.The story and sound effects are very immersive, contributing to a chilling cinematic atmostphere where you can feel the loneliness of your civilization lost in space as you build your fleet while preparing for explorations and enemy encounters. The learning curve is easy compared to other strategy games so feel free to give it a try. It's worth it!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												I didn't like this as much as I thought I would.  I never played the original version, so I'm just now experiencing Homeworld in the Remastered Collection.It does seem to be a good 3D RTS engine and watching the ships in combat is amazing.  The storyline and plot is also interesting, at least as far as I played.  Is probably a game worth looking into or trying at least once, if its on sale.  But I think in today's RTS world, its a bit behind, even with the updated graphics.  I stopped playing at about the 6th mission for several reasons:1.  Even playing normal difficulty, the AI is brutal throwing in larger ships like Frigates and even Destroyers very soon in the game, I think about the 4th or 5th mission.  Before you have even had a chance to build more than a few of them.  So unless you have researched and crank out some serious frigates, you will be toast.  I think its the I've read some walkthroughs and you can "cheese" your way through these missions by capturing with salvage frigates, but that seems cheesy and more like an exploit, then winning with combat. 2.  Resources are limited and always seem to be on the same place in the map,  A group of asteroids or a cloud of interstellar gas - always in about the same places.   it makes it kind of boring and also makes the game a bit unforgiving, if you mess up and lose to many ships or make a mistake, the campaign mission is pretty much over, or the next campaign mission will be impossible because you don't have enough resources to build new ships or do research.3.  I got bored with the space theme.  It looks beautiful flying around for a while and watching ship combat, but then after a bit its boring to me, compared to land based RTS games.  In the land based ones, you can use the terrain to your advantage in attacking and setting up bases, and building defenses.  But in Homeworld, you are pretty much thrown into a system with your unmovable base ship stuck in one place.  With tons of empty space around you.  I just found that the combat got kind of boring because its mostly scrambling around to send groups of ships to certain places, without much strategy or base defense building involved.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												One of my favorite strategy games of ALL TIME!!This franchise and me go back a ways...i was a younger teen when Homeworld came out and I had to have it!  The game was the first of its kind. at least it was for me anyways...Unfortunately the consoles started to show their faces, and I was taken from pc to consoles.It would be years before I would buy a pc again and I bought a laptop. Good thing im a game horder, because I still had my copy of Homeworld. Got back into the game and relived soo many memories.....and soon I would stumble upon Homeworld 2...."What?" I had no idea that there was a sequel....as I said it had been years....so I magicaly found a copy online and man was this a even BETTER experiance than the original!....Alas...It would be short lived as my laptop would die, and I found myself once more sucked into the next console generation.....As fate would have it...some more years would go by and this new next gen of consoles would be emerging...and I would not be suckered by this so called "NEW NEXT GEN"...So I went and got myself a high end gaming pc....the bad news is that I would not be able to enjoy my Homeworld games any more....well not to the extent that they once did...as the game did not support higher res grapgics that are out now.But GearBox has done something special by REMASTERING a MASTERPIECE! and once again I can enjoy this amazing franchise once more!!Well done GearBox!...there was alot of bad hype that this company was recieving. But this was done right in soo many ways!Thank you,10/10!!!

												A faithful remaster of my favorite space strategy game of all time.  Possibly my favorite game.  The graphics updates are stunning, and Gearbox has been faithful to patch to improve balancing and fix bugs.  The voice acting is so much better than most strategy games, which is a pet peeve of mine.  There are a few good mods out there too.   If you want a fair challenge, love space strategy or beautiful spaceship design, love the original, or like to watch ships blow up and go boom, then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Still one of, if not, the best space RTS games ever made. What I don't understand is why no one borrowed or evolved the space battle model pioneered by this game, instead developers over the years went the easy/lazy route setting the battlespace on a 2D plane. While remastered was litterally everything I expected it to be, and this is me being greedy, I would have loved to see a HW 2.5 type set up where maybe things the fans liked from HW1 and HW2 were blended to make a rebalanced best of both worlds type thing to add another refreshing dimension to this (still) one of a kind space RTS. Infinitely replayable, ship design, sound, and lighting is top notch. Should be in anyone's library if you're a fan of RTS games. Very highly recommended.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												So, this is it: The good old days are coming back.A new Master of Orion has been anounced, Fallout 4 knocks on the door and Gearbox released a remastered version of Homeworld 1 and 2 combined including a multiplayer mode combining both AND including the old versions, and that is what Iwant to write about here.This IS almost exactly the old Homeworld just with ditched up GFX.The changesGearbox made are mostly positive- like getting rid of the fuel limitation of strikecraft in HW1.One might saythe carrier is almost useless now, and I agree, but refuling the fighters was mostly just annoying.The bad things have mostly returned as well, like the horrible difficulty spikes of HW2. I am a very experienced player and I just don't get past the third mission where I am to protect the shipyard... Maybe there's a trick that Ijust fail to spot.The Multiplayer is still in Beta, but honestly, Idon't see any problems with it after three long skirmishes, it worked perfectly well. I had more Issues with HW1rm where the sound went on the fritz horribly in the last mission.It is really sad, that cataclysm is not includet - it's because the game files have been lost during the transition from barking dog to gearbox or something alike. I really hope they turn up soon and cataclysm will be includet here, because it was rad!So what to say? You loved Homeworld 1 and/or Homeworld 2? Go get this! It's great!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												For all of those who care for a weighted review or whatever, I'd like to point it out: this is basically a love-letter, from a fan-boy (who's not a boy for a long time now).This is the game that brought all the beauty of the space before my eyes, when I was younger. This is the game I waited for oh so long to be either continued or be remastered. And when the news came in, I was happy that I could once again meet the Hiigarans and listen to that incredible soundtrack and command fleets and... oh so much more. Even though so many years have passed it still gives me that incredible sense of... adventure, that I somehow miss in modern games. And even though I know all the story from A to Z, it is still incredibly fun and exciting to go through it. The gameplay is not at all weaker, and the enhanced graphics only make it more immersive.There are some people who give the game 'thumbs down' either because they think it's wrong to use the name of the older version (or its score on the Metacritics). There are some, who think little bugs are... well, it seems they think those are kind of sin.But I disagree. This is one of the best remastered games I have ever played, And I know for a fact that I will enjoy playing it. Again... and, then, again =)Now, the policy requires to me give pros and cons:Pros:- Excellent graphics- Incredible OST (I wonder why do they not sell it separately?)- Involving story- God, it's Homeworld, how can it not be a pro? )Cons:- Little bugs- Some balancing problemsBut after all, who cares? ) It is only up to you to decide whether you want it or not. But I would strongly recommend to play it, because, who knows, we may have a HW3 someday... perhaps even sooner than HL3 =)

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I was 17 when this game first came out. And that amaze balls feeling you get when you first play this game is still there. The story is great it is a bit of Battlestar galatica feel to it. The game plays so seemlessly it is fairly brutal in its learning curve tho you got to manage your fleet well keeping your fighters busy getting rid of bombers and corvettes while keeping your capital ships alive, and frigates moving to get the rear and top of other capital ships. It is quite chaotic once the battle commence and you got to be aware of the whole situation zooming in and out of the tactical map and strategic map as well. Focus too much on the big fight and you might face a small yet destructive unit that hits your harvesters on the far end of your map. I rate it highly to anyone whom like RTS games

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Day 1 review:This is a very good remastered version, I'm only 5 missions into the remastered HW1 and thus far it's pretty much as advertised, a remastered version of the original, though it's definately not the same mechanics.  The UI has been redone, and redone very well.  The original musical scores so far have remained and most of the voice actors are also the same, though the updated dialog seems a bit rushed on delivery and a "small" amount of that original emotion has been lost, but overall still very good, and if you've never played before you'll probably never notice but is something to enjoy in the classic version if you opt to play that.The graphics are fantastic and the new animations are quite impressive, love the new booms and kapows!  There are a few issues in the remastered version, formations aren't quite working right, support ships aren't supporting correctly, and you're not able to select your desired race in the campaign mode anymore.  So the old tactics need to altered to compensate for the new mechanics a bit, hopefully we'll see updates to correct these issues.Overall a very respectful and appreciated update to an old classic I actually still played from time to time.

Yes, there has been some changes done between HW1 -> Remastered but for those doubtful, please realize that HW1 and HW2 were two completely different games that just shared the same story and some units that looked alike.  SO making it possible to play all races in the new game, some sacrifices had to be made to bring balance to the game...it is a step in the right direction, that is why multiplayer is still BETA.  Other than that you can still play the campaigns, make sure you have the DLC checked for them though otherwise they will not show in the game. content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Day 1 review:This is a very good remastered version, I'm only 5 missions into the remastered HW1 and thus far it's pretty much as advertised, a remastered version of the original, though it's definately not the same mechanics.  The UI has been redone, and redone very well.  The original musical scores so far have remained and most of the voice actors are also the same, though the updated dialog seems a bit rushed on delivery and a "small" amount of that original emotion has been lost, but overall still very good, and if you've never played before you'll probably never notice but is something to enjoy in the classic version if you opt to play that.The graphics are fantastic and the new animations are quite impressive, love the new booms and kapows!  There are a few issues in the remastered version, formations aren't quite working right, support ships aren't supporting correctly, and you're not able to select your desired race in the campaign mode anymore.  So the old tactics need to altered to compensate for the new mechanics a bit, hopefully we'll see updates to correct these issues.Overall a very respectful and appreciated update to an old classic I actually still played from time to time.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												I am really impressed at the hardwork that has gone into this game to breath new life into it.  Yes, there has been some changes done between HW1 -> Remastered but for those doubtful, please realize that HW1 and HW2 were two completely different games that just shared the same story and some units that looked alike.  SO making it possible to play all races in the new game, some sacrifices had to be made to bring balance to the game...it is a step in the right direction, that is why multiplayer is still BETA.  Other than that you can still play the campaigns, make sure you have the DLC checked for them though otherwise they will not show in the game.  Graphics are absolutely oustanding, brings back so many memories.Phantex Enthoo ProCPU:AMD 8350RAM: 32GBVID: Sapphira R9 290X w/4gb memory.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												Tu planeta de origen yace en llamas y destrucción, y tu comandas a los sobrevivientes de tu raza en una cruzada para encontrar un nuevo comienzo tras encontrar un mapa galactico. Tu viaje te llevara por lugares peligrosos y quienes destruyeron tu mundo quieren terminar el trabajo.Este juego te llevara a explorar los confines de la galaxia comandando una flota entera, desde navez caza hasta y covertas, hasta los pesos pesados como los destructores y  cruceros de batalla. Las batallas serán epicas y tu las experimentaras en toda su gloria y horror. La interfaz de comando es muy facil de usar y facilita mucho el hecho de que estas comandando una flota de cientos. La historia del juego es muy buena y lo mejor es que tienes los dos juegos remasterizados con graficas actuales, una pieza maestra.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												I've always loved RTS games with a serious passion since I first started playing video games and I must say that this one is the most fun I've had in years  playing a game.Cons-Because there are so few id rather start with these:One issue many people harp on in the review section is that when you form up an attack formation that the ships end up running into eachother, getting in each other's ways and leaving eachother behind which is kind of a problem when you start getting the late game slow-but-powerful ships mixxed in with your Multi-gun corvets and bombers leaving the powerful capital ships behind. The tutorial says that when ships are in a formation that they willconform to the slowwest ship's speed which makes me think that this will soon be resolved but for now(7/3/15) it is still a problem for me.Pros-Pretty much everything else that the game involves. the combat is well scaled and balanced for the size and scale of the map. Different kinds of ship classes and research trees throughout a game make it very fun and gave me a good three hours of gameplay when I first sat down which is a very good thing with someone as busy as I. The gameplay is slow paced which makes me believe tat we wont be seeing a competitive league for Homeworld but thats not a problem. Final Verdict-The game is very fun and will provide you with hours and hours of entertainment for the lovers of RTS games. The learning curve is kind of steep but at the same time very refreshing compared to games that hold your hand the whole way through. There are some small problems with squadron attack formation but otherwise a very polished and and smooth game that people of all ages can enjoy.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												Buy it on sale only. Why? I love homeworld, i did the first time around. But this is not that game. Homeworld 1 RM is rebuilt in the old homeworld 2 engine, polished up. Anyone who recalls the gutting homwqorld 2 took will recall the complete change in gameplay. Home world 1`s campaign in the 2 engine is horrible and has to be modded to be more like it should be to make several missions make sense. But but but ... ignore the fan boys at this point, as look at missions 3 and 11. If you do really well in mission 1 and 2 and start mission 3 with anything resembling a fleet... you loose the mission due to homeworld 1s scaling enemys fleets in the first 30 seconds. By mission 9s end you should have a decent fleet. Mission 10 willl punish this until you figure it out. Either way youll start mission 11 with a decent or full+ fleet. Only to be met with scaled enemies ending the mission in 30 seconds again. Both times the annihilate a mission objective before you can bring anything to the incidents. Home world 1 RM is gutted to play like homeworld 2 RM. As above the scaling fleets.. original HW had scaling yes but not as horrific as HW2. Also HW 1 (original) you could opt for a strategy that met the storyline of survival and rebuilding by cappturing almost every enemy ship with your own secialised ships. Now theyve been limited to 14 and that strategy is out the window. As its a chore to do it and if you do it well and get your huge fleet, the scaling enemy will annihilate you. HW2 RM .. gutted the already original capped ships even more. Most vets didnt like the changes to game play. The ♥♥♥♥♥ily re implimented movers we never noticed reskinned from HW1 ... the 4 marine ships which were and are♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥... No cataclism cos they cant find the original code ... Stupid lazy fks could have ripped the game code from any disk and rebuilt it on the 2 engine, but no. Even though they have the rights and license no.. They need the source code. (yeah that thing hundreds of people across the world got given thats still out there..) Is the game fun. Yes. IS it enjoyable with thte issues of remastering, yeah, if you mod and buy it cheap, its ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. Dont listen to anyone saying it adds chalenge, they dont understand whats been lost in translation from 1 and 2 onto 2s remastered engine. Buy it, but cheap. Its great fun. Mod it to old style game specs and its the best game youll ever play in its genre. Bonus it comes, usually, with original 2 games to compare to. So anyone buying it is getting 4 games. IF you can get it under a tenner on a bundle or dale, its a no brainer. Games brill, devs need a kick up the bum. But least they brought it back into the light of day. Even if they did sodomise it a bit on the way.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Honestly I can't say anything about the campains of thomeworld remastered I have just been doing multiplayer or skirms vs AI.  I have read some of the negative reviews and they are not true.  I put my fighters in formations, and can choose what stance they use.  Mixing homeworld 1 and 2 races is an awesome idea.  Both sides have their ups and downs.  I have played a HWI race the taiidan in multiplayer and whomped some serious♥♥♥♥♥  I also played the vaygr.  I stay away from the goodie two-show hiigarans and kushan.  That being said the multiplayer is quite unstable.  People drop for no reason.  I can only assume the server is jacked up.  When the games do get off the ground it is really fun.  I played a ffa match with 6 players that almost lasted 2 hours.  This game kicks most modern-day games asses.  It was good 15 years ago and it is even better now.  Their is a bit of a learning curve though as each race is quite different.  So just practice them all against the computer, see whitch one or more is right for you.  then have a blast.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Great game back in 1999 and 2004 and now looks even better! Tons of fun to be had with this game.Having that been said there are a few issues I think need to be said for those who played both games back when they originally came out. First off, the tactics that were replaced in HW1 kinda kill some of the gameplay. Fighters and ships dont hold formation when attacking as they did in the original game. As soon as they engage on an enemy they all just seem to fly around all willy nilly, fighters especially. Second, the game glitched and gave me way too many resources on the third mission in and made the rest of the game too easy after that. I didn't have to plan attacks or harvest wrecks to scrape up precious resouces. Nope, just build wrecklessly and send constant waves at the enemy. The biggest let down, in my opinion, is once I beat the game I was not rewarded with that sweet jam by YES. Seriously, that made me sad not to hear that. Honestly, nothing could take us far enough, emotion, far enough... You get the picture. But despite all of that, It's still a great game that everyone that loves RTS and space operas should enjoy. It's still fun to play to this day.

												Fairly good space rts for the price, nice visuals overall and a 3 dimensional combat system. The only downside is i usually find i have too limited of resources to go all out at times. But that does make it an actual challenge for those of you who know what tham means in a strategy game. spam = fail. Overthought out maticulously executed plans = win, maybe. NOTE for those who have not played before capturing during campaign is extremely helpfull.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												I see a few reviews about this game being buggy, and apparently I lucked out. The only bug I encountered was one that caused graphocs to appear transparent if I had something that could overlay my game screen running alongside - in my case it was Trillian, my chat client.I guess I got lucky and didn't encounter any bugs other than that, save two random crashes during HW1 campaign, and they were both within moments of a save, so I wasn't even that mad.As to an actual review, well, let's get started.Graphics: Okay, so it's a remaster. The original game was pretty, and this is essentially the HD remake of it. Of course it's pretty. It's VERY pretty.  Not only is it very pretty, it's also not that system-heavy. My box is comfortably mid-range with a decent GPU, and I can run things pretty much full tilt with no frame drops or hiccups of any kind on an intel/NVIDIA setup. Space is beautiful, and I don't mind sometimes losing a couple of ships for idly spinning the camera around and admiring the view. Ship detail is excellent, and the combat scarring is a nice touch, though I'm rarely zoomed in enough to truly admire it. Sound: Faithfully reproduced sounds and bringing back the original voice actress for Karan S'Jet from HW1 to reprise her role for the HW2 campaign both made me happy in special places. The sound of ion cannons blaring away at a target, my collectors telling me to expect delays, the pilots calling out a little too calmly/matter-of-factly that there's a breach in the starboard fusion chamber, or just that awesome warble of entering/exiting hyperspace... Ah, the memories that came rushing back. Sound is excellent, crisp, and nothing is too repetitive unless you're like me and reload saves a bunch of times if things go a little too far south/you secretly suck at video games like I do.UI: Yes, the UI is getting it's own section here. Wonderfully redesigned based on HW2, however my biggest grips with the game is also here. Considering it's a startegy game, you will spend a considerable amount of time interacting with menus. These menus are all tucked nicely to one side of the screen, and stay until dismissed. Which means for me, they pretty much just stay there. And that's fine, because they aren't obtrusive in any way. Except that the selected ship list is too small at scale 1. Yes, you can scale the UI in game. A very nice touch. Except that, even at 1080p (since my monitor goes no higher) anything above 1 makes other parts of the UI waaay too big. I really don't need the menu button in the top left of my screen to take up a THIRD of my real estate. And that's at scale 3! Fortunately, there's a mod on the workshop right now that remedies this issue, but having to pause the sampaign to change my UI scale so I could properly select a ship just to pause again to scale back down so I can see things got annoying. If you're running at 1080, I suggest you download the UI resize mod.Gameplay: Ah, the meat of the review. The gameplay is solid. Super solid. Like, really effing good. So you know how most RTS games give you units and you move them around on the ground? And you know how even in most space RTS games, you're still given a 2D plane? As if you were still dealing with the ground? Well not here. You have a full 360 degrees to move your ships through. That's three axes. That's forward/back, left/right, UP/DOWN. There's really little practical use for it in a tactical sense, since your sensors also cover 360 dgerees, and the direction of an attack won't matter so much as everything has the same freedom of movement, but it does allow for some very good strategic moves. For example, I played a friend who had never played homeworld before. His first game ever was versus me. I took it easy on a seasoned RTS veteran. I was only half surprised, then, when he showed up at my mothership with the fleet I SHOULD have had at that moment. I then grinned as my hyperspace module finished construction. I jumped to a nowhere bottom corner of the map and survived on mobile refineries and a carrier while building my fleet in secret, jumping to another random corner any time his scouts got near. By the time he managed to find me with probes, I had amassed enough of a fleet to jump eveything I had, including my mothership, directly in the engines of his mothership. His fault for not building a gravity well generator. His fleet, which had moved to engage mine where it was being staged, didn't return in time to save him. The gameplay isn't all awesome, though. As others have pointed out, there are issues that are irritating to old fans like myself. Ship stances - aggressive, defensive, and passive tactics - used to divert power to weapons, engines, or keep it balanced, respectively. This made ships behave very differently. With aggressive tactics, nobody really flew around much back in the day. They just parked at optimal firing range and unloaded. This was a great way to take out isolated capital ships. Sphere up on a target and go aggressive. Reinforcements arrive? Fighter screen and defensive, watch your fleet suddenly scatter, cap ships line up and start orbiting, and fighters swarm incessantly. No longer. Now it is simply a visual difference in how the HW2 squads fly in their individual formations - which used to be a visual clue for what tactics fighters/corvettes were using. Also, group/fleet formations, as mentioned by others also fall apart in combat. The moment anybody is in weapons range, the formation is over. Every man for himself. Tactics don't change anything, and the only thing the formation changes is who gets to shoot first. After that, it just becomes a really pretty furball.Targeting subsystems used to be hugely important. I can't tell you how many ships I saved because I sent bombers after the missile batteries/ion cannons on BCs as soon as I could. Gave my cap ships a fighting chance, and made me feel like a badass commander. Now it's basically  "1-A" (Select your ball of death with 1, press A to attack) game for victory with a few exceptions - mostly the last couple of missions/moments where you need to do something specific for victory that isn't "Kill everything that isn't yours."Even with these issues, I would still pay $35 for this game. AAA games today don't grab me quite like Homeworld did. When the original launched, I put many hundreds of hours in to it. Ditto the sequel. I also know the modding community is very strong, and the developers are actually working WITH the mod community to make sure the game can do things THEY expect it to do. And considering there are mods like Complex, which makes things like weapon placement and individualk ship placement/positioning REALLY matter, not to mention adding so many new ships that it may as well be a different game... Yeah, this game is worth the price of admission. And it's technically 4 games, considering you're getting the original HW1&2 as part of the deal, though playing those is pretty painful by comparison. There's a reason I mentioned the overhauled UI, and the original IS 15 years old. Pretty for 15, but still definitely outdated.Nutshell: If you want the hands down best 3D space RTS you will play this year and likely ever, look no further. Story, graphics, gameplay are all excellent, a lively and talented modding scene, and just a damn good experience. If you want my advice, buy the game, smoke some pot, dim the lights, turn up the volume, and go on a journey across the Galaxy like nothing you've experienced yet.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Well 16 hours through and campaign complete.Admittedly without formations things were a little more difficult, but not so much that it's unpassable (I just passed it!)  I played the original when it came out, and pre-ordered here. I can't say that without these features that this game isn't HomeWorld.  The story, the voice acting, the music, the gameplay, it's still all top notch.   This is what really made Homeworld.  So I have to naysay the naysayers.   You still get the originals if you need to be that purist.  Maybe they'll patch it, but the game was very releasable at the point it is today.  It's still a fun game that can invoke emotion in you.For folks who have never played...Homeworld was created during a time 3D on a computer was still in its infancy.  There was a lot of games made at the time that were duds, and a few greats like Homeworld.    The game did well enough to warrant 2 sequels and a port to Mac.  You play the part of a exiled race who discovers warp technology.  As soon as you fire up your engines, those that exiled you come and destroy the only home you had, the desert world they left you stranded on 4000 years earlier.   As the fleet, you are responsible for the last remaining survivors of your planet.  There is no turning back.As you progress through the game, you research new ships, each with unique abilities.  Levels are laid out in a way where you have to put every newly learned ability to use, almost like a Puzzle.If you've ever watched The Angry Video Game Nerd talk about how perfect Mega Man X is for teaching you how to play, through gameplay, Homeworlds puzzles are a bit like that.One peice of advice I can give... Save.. Save often.  It sucks to have spent an hour trying to get through a level, only to die right before the end.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												As I write this review Ive at this point only played though HW1 remastered. As well as a skirmish or two versus the AI.So let's focus on what's good first.First off, it looks AMAZING. I can't possibly say that enough. They also did some minor tweaks to the campaign to make things interesting, I wont say what. No spoilers. Other than that, everything you loved about the original is either in place an still their to love, or improved and modernized. So you can expect a good experience if you pony up the bucks to re-live the game. There are however a few bugs...Which is what I'll get on to. I know, a release version game with bugs that need patched. Shocking. Well I say get over it. What can you expect with the publishers we have strangling the PC game industry? As far as the bugs, Capital movement and formation making needs a do-over. It's managable, but needs work. For instance, capitals at times in formation will go full retard and stop if a an obstruction is in their path like say, an asteroid. There's also some rendering issues in regards to dust clouds. This was escpecially bad on one mission, but there are workarounds and again, these things typically go to the top of the bug squashing list so i dont expect it to be there the next time I feel like giving the campaign a whirl.Other than that I noticed no other major bugs. The game plays great, if greater than the original. I'm glad to have spent the money on it.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Its Homeworld. Nuff said really......but if you dont want more, its all been hauled up to date graphically and the soul of the games are there. Is it any good though? well I have 100%ed it, which is pretty rare in my steam library. Homeworld 1 is still better than Homeworld 2 mainly because the story goes a bit iffy in 2, not to mention the very elastic autobalance. Homeworld 1 is pretty buggy in this incarnation though;Fighter craft are a complete waste of space due to the fact its been done in the Homeworld 2 engine where they need squadrons to be effective and the biggest issue of all is that formations just dont work. Ships line up prettily until given any order than they start clumping up like a bunch of 5 year olds playing football)If you can get past those problems (and its certainly not hard to do so - just requires a little tactics adjustment)One last thing - dont spend forever capturing everything you can in Homeworld 1. Once you get bigger capital ships you soon realise that in this remake since all of the damage has been upped frigates are made of paper and die before they get into range of a battlecruiser, so really its just a waste of your time, no matter how appealing that massive ball of ion frigates looks on THAT one level. You know what I'm talking about homeworld players...

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Homeworld is my all time favorite game. I couldn't wait when I heard it had a new life. The remastered version is excellent and worthy of a purchase. It needs some polish, that the first patch has already gone a long way towards seeing out. The only major gripe I have is the complete lack of the formation feature from HW1. Strike craft do not operate as they should, and act like they do in HW2 which is the engine Remastered is built from. All other aspects are top notch. Mod support, amazing graphics, staying true to the tone, sound and look of the originals. I really hope this is a new start for the Homeworld universe.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												It's  difficult to recommend or not not recommend this game. I did play both Homeworld games, and i think that HW2 lost something of what made HW1 great : tactics, formations, and most importantly 3d manouering. If you played HW1 you probably noticed that in HW2 ships manouver only on a 2d plane first, and when moving vertically they stay aligned to the horizontal plane, while in HW1 they actually turn towards their destination (e.g. if they move up, they move nose up) and hw2 they only turn in one plane, and move up or down without changing their orientation (they stay parallel to a virtual ground). In other words, its not really 3D anymore.   Also, formations next to useless : they dont fight in formations. Annoyance is that ships has a tendency just do whatever they want - like you are capturing a ship they will quite happily shoot it into pieces despite giving them the stand down order.On the other hand, there is a lot of eye candy. If you preferred the simplified HW2 over HW1, this is a game for you.  I wanted to say I dont recommend, but this is still not a bad game to play and i can't say i did regret the purchase. I wish they would remastered HW1 instead of HW2 as the main game. But have the classics to play :)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												This...This I've been hungering for since it was announced that Gearbox bought the rights.  Homeworld 1, 2 and Cataclysm (sadly not available) are some of the RTS games that I loved the most.  Gearbox did not disappoint.  The originals are here along with the upgraded versions, which bring the graphics up to modern standards.  Remember how amazing the graphics were in '99?  You'll feel the same about the remastered versions now.  They are fantastic.  The level of detail can be increased enough to send many modern, if not top of the line, graphics adapters into a stutter.  The gameplay is fun and exciting.Granted that many RTS games now have multiple resource types and Homework only has one, but the focus is not on resource production.  The focus is on  building a fleet comprised of ships that will match the fleet that opposes you.  I have literally seen a fleet of destroyers picked apart by bombers and gunships.  I have thrown a handful of destroyers against a group of 15-ish frigates and handed their♥♥♥♥♥to them on a platter.  This game is all about knowing which ships to produce to come out on top.Not enough can be said of the thoughtfulness and caring that went into the restoration of the original games.  The audio briefings has been cleaned up a to a large degree and sounds much better than the originals.  The graphics in the mission briefings are also improved, showing more detail.If RTS is the genre you love and you haven't played Homeworld you need to give it a try.  If you have any nostalgic memories of it at all then you need to get it again.  And if possible, find yourself a USB powered mothership statue.  I did, and I love it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2016
												A longtime Mac user, I've wanted to play the Homeworld series for years, but I also wanted to start with the original. With the release of Homeworld: Remastered on SteamPlay, I had an opportunity to experience the story from the beginning; an opportunity I seized upon. But even with updated graphics, the original has NOT aged well. I didn't encounter any of the bugs that others have complained about, but the game is sorely missing a modern feature of any major RTS: speed control. Jump in, analyze the objectives, formulate a response... and then wait 20 minutes while your ships move around the map. Messed up the strategy? Wait another 20 minutes while your next battle group traverses the map. Really messed up? Start the mission from scratch.While speed control was apparently added in Homeworld 2, playing the original without it is nothing less than a painful waste of time. What's more, the game sorely needs some light in-game training on how best to deploy new ships and technologies, things which instead are thrown at you with only minimal explanation as to their use. I wanted to enjoy Homeworld very badly, but the shortcomings of the original have made that impossible. The amount of time the game eats up also meant I was well-past the 2 hours of gameplay refund-cutoff by the time I realized I couldn't play it anymore.

Posted: March 4, 2015
												In the infinite majesty of space, cruelty and beauty can be found in equal measure. A race brought to the very brink of destruction through the violation of a treaty signed millenia ago, left marooned in space clinging to a technology salvaged from ancient ancestors and a single guiding star. Home.This sets the stage for one of the greatest space strategy games of all time, Homeworld. A game that has rarely been aspired to since, and a game filled with ideas that even to this day are rarely even touched upon. Only now a few daring indie developers dare brave the complexities that represent true three dimensional space combat and even then they have yet to come even close to what Homeworld achieved. It was lightning in a bottle, a cult classic synthesised from a pace that was stately enough to appreciate the sheer majesty that the game inspired with its' sweeping scale, a soundtrack that was borne of classical tones and distant melancholy, and a story that took you on a true campaign, where your units would carry over from mission to mission, along with your resource pool. These are all concepts that in most current campaigns are oft ignored, set aside for flashy Michael Bay style set pieces and much shallower, more simplistic stories. Homeworld told stories of shades of grey, of culture, of alien races with diverse backgrounds and lore, of imperialism, of a nebula home to a technologically advanced enclave that sought refuge and peace within the sanctity of drifting ghostlike threads.Homeworld Remastered is a restoration of that premise, Gearbox have carefully and considerately taken the Homeworld 2 interface (the better one) and the source assets, placed them in a more modern, more capable and more mod friendly engine, and then carefully brought the game up to current generation standards, with lighting, depth of field, better framerates, higher resolutions, better texturing, cleaned up the sound work, the whole lot. The result quite literally is Homeworld as viewed through the "rose tinted glasses of memory", it's how we always imagined it was in our heads, even if our then much less meaty PC's couldn't QUITE give us the experience that we wished for.The change is stark when placed side by side, it's hard to imagine when you fire up remastered thinking that the ships -didn't- look that impressive before, but when you play the original you then are reminded with a shock that yes, they were kinda blocky and yes, the textures were kinda flat back in the day. That's all gone now, the ships really -do- look like their concept art, they really do move with the kind of majesty and detail that we all imagined they did, the mothership is just crammed with detail, and everywhere you look, there's something that just looks *better* than it did before. The sound too, is crisper, with all the sound assets being cleaned up and provided at a higher fidelity, with the music being remastered at a higher bitrate, again, no changes that alter the fabric of the game, but a subtle re-weaving that change the feel into the game we always remembered it as.You do get a lot of game for your money too, for the asking cost you'll get both Homeworld 1 and 2 remastered, along with their original source games in case you feel like a trip down nostalgia lane and want to do some side by side comparisons (I suggest you do), you also get the multiplayer which brings all four factions into multiplayer together, which is sure to open up some interesting games once they get the code all sorted out and out of "beta" (for whatever that term means these days), and you'll get what is quite easily still the greatest space opera strategy ever to grace the PC.Gearbox did good. Everyone was holding their breath because I could imagine the kind of fury that would have been issued forth had they scuffed this, but no. They did good, this has made me a happy tiger, Homeworld is a game that deserved to be brought back, it deserved this remastering, and what you get is quite comfortably the "definitive" version of Homeworld. Prepare for a journey unlike any you'll find, this one truly is something special.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												Gearbox has (re)created a beautiful-looking space strategy game that will impress those new to the series but leave oldschool Homeworld fans bitterly dissapointed. If you're looking for some fun multiplayer action you'll love this game but if you want to revisit the classic Homeworld campaign I cannot recommend it unless there's a serious effort by the devs to address the many problems in the launch version. Read below for detailed comments.THE GOOD:- Absolutely gorgeous graphics. Everything looks very nice and with some minor tweaking plays smoothly even on my     not-so-good laptop.- The original artstyle in the cinematics has been faithfully recreated and, again, it all looks very nice.- Excellent, engaging story in HW1:R, same as the 1999 classic.- Good voice acting and music bring the experience to life.- Multiplayer is, despite some balance issues between the HW1 and HW2 races, simply a blast to play.THE BAD:- The game uses a modified HW2 engine which does not seem to work very well with the HW1 campaign/units. I'm not sure how many of the problems listed below are due to engine limitations and how many can be patched in, if someone more knowlegeable about HW modding can chip in on this I'll edit the review accordingly.- Strike craft formations/tactics simply do not work for the HW1 units. Strike craft will assume a formation when ordered to but after combat is joined they will attack seemingly random targets on their own flight paths regardless of tactics settings used, making concentrating fire to specific targets impossible and leading to a lot of losses.- The HW1 remastered campaign in general lacks polish. Missing/bugged mission triggers, wonky AI behaviour (resource collectors in particular will randomly stop harvesting after dropping off their loads), ship engine sound effects persisting after zooming in and then out on some units, sensor manager sometimes just deciding to stop working altogether, repair corvettes apparently not working at all and simply atrocious difficulty scaling.  Expect to reload a lot to get through some missions.- The dynamic difficulty scaling seems way out of whack for the campaign. The HW1 campaign now uses the (almost universally despised) dynamic difficulty scaling system originally introduced by HW2. In a nutshell, the enemies you'll face are generated depending on your fleet composition at the start of a mission. Some people like this idea, some don't. Regardless of how one feels about it, the system clearly has not been playtested enough as the seeming lack of hard caps on enemy numbers will lead to some unwinnable fights for players who like to build up their fleet. For example, capturing a good number of enemy corvettes in mission 2 will cause an overwhelming number of enemies to spawn in the following mission, leading to a game over before the introductory cutscenes are even finished.CONCLUSION: I'm really torn on this but I'll have to go with a no recommendation until the flawed port of the HW1 campaign and strike craft mechanics are addressed. If you're a returning HW1 veteran definately hold off on this until the game is (hopefully) patched and/or modded to make the experience closer to the original. On the other hand those new to the series will no doubt appreciate the engaging story of the campaign. The fun multiplayer can also help a lot so consider what you want of the game and take this review as it is.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Well... As it stands right now they made HW2 okay but completely ruined HW1 in every way shape and form. Formations in the REAL Homeworld don't work properly, they don't stay in proper formation. Capital ships can't maneuver worth beans, Destroyers are no longer the ultimate utility ship of the fleet anymore. They were designed in HW1 to keep pace with and LEAD the frigate lines. Now they're slow, lumbering beasts that just♥♥♥♥♥♥me off. Frigates are now made of wet paper bags and fighters are slow and unmaneuverable, meaning point defenses and even heavier weapons could destroy them. Corvettes are now pointless to build. Basically you just build fighters bombers and super-capitals only and they are all that is worth building.The GUI is NOTHING like the original Homeworld which let you have a very clean experience which didn't block anything out. If you didn't need to see the GUI at that moment, it wasn't there. One of the things that made Homeworld loveable was that it assumed you were intelligent.Singleplayer's adaptive difficulty from HW1 is now gone from what I can tell and it is pathetically easy for an experienced HW Vet. I had little trouble in the first few missions, which was dissappointing to say the least.Fuel consumption no longer exists for fighters which means that when I eventually reach the Garden of Kadesh I can expect to be utterly massacred by the Kadeshi. This makes the Support Frigate a useless item. Honestly, why have them anymore at all?! The whole ballance is gone by removing fuel consumption, barring the other things they've utterly mucked up.I'm happy that they thought it worth the effort to do a remastered edition but they sacrificed the original Homeworld ENTIRELY in order to satisfy the Homeworld 2 players. The thing is... There is a LOT more Homeworld 1 fans that stayed true and bought this than there were Homeworld 2 fans (at least if my group of friends is any indication).Gearbox... Hear us! Fix your rather glaring mistakes! Homeworld 1 should have been the priority... Especially since THAT is the one that won Game of the Year in 1999. And lets be honest... It had some pretty TALL competition back then for that title. It didn't just win Strategy Game of the Year, it won overall Game of the Year.... Frankly I want a refund because this wasn't true to the Homeworld legacy at all... As far as I am concerned the basic models for the ships are the same and then cut-scenes are the same. The rest is garbage.
