Posted: January 10
												As a big fan of the original Homeworld titles (HW, HW:C, HW2) I felt compelled to write my own review of the "Remastered" collection. If you're looking to spend money through Steam to buy these titles, I encourage you not to. The "Remastered" HW is a huge disappointment, plagued with a sense of "Beta." I have the original HW and HW2 disc software and Win 10 on my PC's, and they have no issues running in compatibility. The Remastered collections crashes, freezes, and is plagued with bugs (as of 1/10/2017). The Remastered collection, I will admit has smoother renderings and neat eye candy. Unfortunately, being built on a broken HW2 platform, which IMO was not an improvement over the original HW, is even worse since the RM version is a severely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ized HW2 platform, hence broken. All in all, if you really want to play HW & HW2, I recommend picking up the original software disc's (amazon, ebay, ect.,) and don't waste your money as I have. I wish I could get a refund.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
 Gearbox speculated on the Originals fanbase to drive the Hypetrain...when they decided to actually charge  32€  for this.Someone in the forum once wrote: "Ten years ago, this would have been called "HD-mod" and it would have been free. Today its called "Remastered" and costs 32 bucks" Oh BTW, look at this gem:


YouTube™ Video: Problems with formations and tactics in Homeworld 1 Remastered 

			Views: 8,615		



According to veterans of the original games, this reduces combat efficience of your vessels drastically. Which is fun in general, but this game also got "dynamic difficulty" or as i call it "Hurl so much s*hit at ya winning is almost impossible"-tactic.While its almost nonexistent in HW 1 RE (i was invincible after boarding my first battleship), HW 2 RE just loves to kick you in the groin.First you´ll learn that boarding changes from HW1 to HW2, instead of small salvage-corvettes you now have much bigger Marine-Frigates, which are weak as s*ht.As soon as they´re spotted, EVERYONE goes for them. Doesnt matter at all how many ships you use as decoys. So when you actually manage to cap a big enemy, youll be proud. "Wow, i capped a big ship, now my fleet´s awesome! Man that feels good!"  you´ll say. And then you reach the next mission. And then the game goes  "Whats that?! A big ship and YOU control it ?!?! PREPARE THE ARMADA!!! GET DAT MUDDAFOCKA!!!!!" Then you´ll end up getting destroyed. You load the last mission, scrap your fleet down to the basics and thus artificially cheat the difficulty down. Conclusion:  32€, no. Just no. Not for 32 Euros!

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												This game is fantastic! Taking me back to playing it day one back in 1999. However i will say this, the learning curve for HW1 remasterd is far less then what was required back in 1999 (the jump from mission to mission early on was much harder and faster hitting in the enemy) i feel it does lack alot of its depth with the removal of fuel. (had to actualy load up my old HW1 on my old system to see the differences) The game is still fantastic and looks great, UI is different which took some getting use to but easily jump back into and play. I will forever miss the how difficult this game was in 1999 for single player and how many hours it took to advance through the first 5 missions.*EDIT*so after playing hours in this game i have come to realise that Homeworld Remastered is a huge let down. The stratigy requirements of the first Homeworld where amazing and required so much more work and thought to use formations and flight tactics. Plus the physics engine/bullets are completely different now, it is using an RNG so shooting and moving is irrelavent. Very sad to see HW1 ported into HW2. HW2 was a step back, still enjoyable but nothing compared to its big brother.Yes the lack of fuel is a bumer but no game changer. I had orginally recommended this game, now i have changed my mind because its not Homeworld it use to be. Still a fun game but its no homeworld. Very disappointing to see Homeworld redone this way. I have not played homeworld 2 remastered yet,not really feeling it right now because of the changes with Homeworld and all the bugs in the game it a huge let down. So if you play this enjoy all the bugs to include huge game changer bugs (skipping cut scences and screwing up the spawn so you never have to fight any enemy or just a couple ships but not the endless onslaught it should have been) also the combat is totaly different and far easyer, however that being said always keep your salvage corvettes on hand! free ships! (oh whats with the AI not shooting salvage corvettes or harvesters? i remember the AI destroying them when they showed up now.) all in all, Homeworld is a fantastic game, Homeworld Remastered is a mediocre remake of one of the worlds best games.

												It's Homeworld 1 and 2 with allot of new paint (especially the former) so I will just state the good bits and bad (mostly linked to HW1). Good bits:Salvage vettes work just as well as they always have... possibly a bit too well(I nicked every single corvette the Turanic Raiders threw at me... if the Standard Corvettes could salvage, neither they nor the missile vettes can use their special abilities, I'd be set for life but as is I gotta keep a 12-16 strong wing of "nice ship you have there...shame if someone were to.... enlighten you of it".Even on medium settings the game looks magnificent, both cutscenes and regular play, and the gameplay of Homeworld 1 is fully intact.Not much else to say, it does everything right almost.Nitpicks: 1. My biggest problem with Remastered is that in Homeworld 1 you can no longer choose to play as either Kushan or Taiidani nor can you alter the paint scheme. The former can be excused, with ample applications of salvette, but the latter is a bit aggravating as a veteran of the original.2. The cutscenes, both between missions and in-game, in Homeworld 1 seem a bit faster than the original versions... it's nitpicky but it kind of feels off to me slightly.3. The streamlining of Homeworld 1 in terms of screens (no more separate build or research screeen from the normal one) though welcomed in certain regards also makes it a bit painful to macromanage everything. In the original the gameplay would pause when you were in the other two screens ergo it is a bit missed somewhat.

												I never write reviews, but this game is basically the second coming for us homeworld crazies. You can read all about the flaws and highlights of this game in other reviews, but I have an odd reccomendation. Unlike most other games, I actually feel like people who are completely new to the series will like this better. To a homeworld fanatic like me, there are little differences that are really jarring, but as a whole, the game is satisfying and enjoyable even in it's current state. If the new devs take some feedback and make a couple of tweaks, this will go down as a worthy remaster of the best RTS of all time.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												Unfortunately this one simply does not live up to the hype. I am an old Homeworld player, and have invested hundreds of hours in all three original releases. So far this version has, in my opinion, taken multiple steps backwards from the originals. Even the classic releases don't play as well as the original versions. I find myself screaming myself hoarse at the frustration of stupid ships that do whatever they feel like, regardless of commands sent, enemy ships that arrive and destroy your fleets many times faster than you can possibly retaliate or build, and limitations that were not it the originals that make no sense at all. Why research a ship type if you can't build it? Why tell a harvester to  gather resources if it is going to park itself the moment it's finished it's first rock? Why leave hundreds of exhausted rocks littering the place? And why weigh the skew so heavily in favor the of the enemy in the single player games that frustration instead of enjoyment is the only possible result? And they lost Cataclysm. Bah!

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												This one is a classic and well worth getting. A lot of reviews say that the game aged well and that Homeworld never really needed the remastering treatment it got. And yet. And yet the work Gearbox did in concert with the original development team, the original voice actors, the concept artists, and the original game's modders shows a loving respect for a series that should never have gone fallow since Homeworld 2 came out. The remastered version is gorgeous and the gameplay hasn't aged a bit. I still tear up hearing the choir singing Barber's Agnus Dei.This is a great game and a work of art well worth having in your collection. I look forward to seeing what Gearbox's enthusiasm will bring to the series in the future.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												This game is fantastic! Taking me back to playing it day one back in 1999. However i will say this, the learning curve for HW1 remasterd is far less then what was required back in 1999 (the jump from mission to mission early on was much harder and faster hitting in the enemy) i feel it does lack alot of its depth with the removal of fuel. (had to actualy load up my old HW1 on my old system to see the differences) The game is still fantastic and looks great, UI is different which took some getting use to but easily jump back into and play. I will forever miss the how difficult this game was in 1999 for single player and how many hours it took to advance through the first 5 missions.*EDIT*so after playing hours in this game i have come to realise that Homeworld Remastered is a huge let down. The stratigy requirements of the first Homeworld where amazing and required so much more work and thought to use formations and flight tactics. Plus the physics engine/bullets are completely different now, it is using an RNG so shooting and moving is irrelavent. Very sad to see HW1 ported into HW2. HW2 was a step back, still enjoyable but nothing compared to its big brother.Yes the lack of fuel is a bumer but no game changer. I had orginally recommended this game, now i have changed my mind because its not Homeworld it use to be. Still a fun game but its no homeworld. Very disappointing to see Homeworld redone this way. I have not played homeworld 2 remastered yet,not really feeling it right now because of the changes with Homeworld and all the bugs in the game it a huge let down. So if you play this enjoy all the bugs to include huge game changer bugs (skipping cut scences and screwing up the spawn so you never have to fight any enemy or just a couple ships but not the endless onslaught it should have been) also the combat is totaly different and far easyer, however that being said always keep your salvage corvettes on hand! free ships! (oh whats with the AI not shooting salvage corvettes or harvesters? i remember the AI destroying them when they showed up now.) all in all, Homeworld is a fantastic game, Homeworld Remastered is a mediocre remake of one of the worlds best games.

												When the game first arrived in 1999, it was amazing to play with great music and atmosphere. content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												A beautiful remastering of an already favourite classic of mine. Homeworld Remastered lives up to its promises and delivers exactly what a remastered version is supposed to. Graphics are touched up to the point of pure art, the sound is clean and clear, the gameplay is smooth and user friendly, and any upgrades necessary from the original are present for all.And of course if you wish to stick to the original, that is also present as well. This remastering has something for everyone, both the old school fans and newcomers, including the branches between those who prefer one version over the other.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												It's Homeworld 1 + 2 in classic and remastered versions.  What else can I say?  I've fired up Homeworld 1 classic and it's pretty much exactly as my existing install.  I've fired up Homeworld 1 Remastered and it's... well it's glorious.  Fairly consistent 90-120FPS with the details turned up past defaults but not maxed, it controls the same, it plays the same, and it looks much better doing it.  This is really all I wanted.For those that don't know of this game, it's the classic 3D RTS developed by the same company that went on to make the Warhammer Dawn of War RTS games.  Homeworld bought a lot of new things to the RTS world upon release, some of which still haven't been bettered.  It's use of 3 dimensional space for positioning your units and attacking being one.  Alongside that the fleet you have created during one mission is the basis of your fleet for the next mission; meaning that careful planning from one stage to the next is essential for success.  Lack of planning and scarce resources can really bite you further into the game.It's worth noting that micromanaging your fleet whilst not essential is advantageous; but you have at least at your desposal settings for stance (aggressive, passive, guarding), formations and basic tools such as guarding units.  Formations are cool, not only do they look good but I they can influence the encounters those units may have and their chances of success.  Though this does seem to bit different (possibly bugged) in Remastered,  you have the Classic one to compare and contrast.In summary this is a good remastering, it polishes where needed, brings things up to date to remaing compatible with newer hardware and leaves the rest unchanged so not tarnishing the memories and reputation of the original games.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												EDIT: (Having played a bit through the HW1 Campaign on Remastered)By all means, Homeworld set the bar on what it really meant to have a space RTS. The original was ground-breaking, and the particularly leisurely pace of the missions as well the ability to keep your fleet between missions reinforced the desire to use tactics, and made each loss of a destroyer a tear-jerker. Needless to say, the game was memorable. Homeworld 2 was another great game, but I wasn't as much a fan of the strict Rock-Paper-Scissors, and completely transient nature of my fleets. I felt like I was rebuilding from scratch every mission, as if my ships were made out of paper. Some of the grander tactics were substituted with spamming the proper counter, making ground, rinse and repeat. I didn't feel as connected to it, but regardless, Some people prefer its interface and overall playablity. In the Remastered Edition, Homeworld 1 is basically Homeworld 2, with a story and ships from the first game. Now, on the surface (and for the first few missions), this works fine. The ability to use Evasive or Aggressive tactics (which increases evasion or accuracy respectively) are gone in favor of general 'behavior'. A few missions later, and I realized that even my strike craft were not staying in formation. If one has played the first game, one may understand the importance of this, as I'm sure many of the other reviews have noted. Now, I can take this loss in Homeworld 2; the game was different. But there is a problem in Homeworld 1. Homeworld 1 fleets and missions were not built with the intention of using the Homeworld 2 engine (duh). First of all, a lack of fuel (for both your units as well as the AI's) is okay... until you reach the Garden of Kadesh, and the main element of the Kadeshi forces is their constant need to refuel. Without fuel, this mission has completely changed in nature. A couple missions later, one is fighting the ghost ship... and the mission has completely changed (due in part to the changes to the ships), one is forced to use Corvettes and Fighters against Anti-fighter and Anti-corvette  frigates (an entire fleet mind you!) without squadron tactics or formations... see the dilemmia? Now, this may seem like I'm ragging on this game pretty hard, but I don't want to come off too hard. This is NOT a bad game, this is still a great game. But, this is not the same game that came out in 1999. It looks like it, (and damn is it beautiful), but it's not the same at the core... not ultimately. As for Homeworld 2, and multiplayer, I'm sure this is going to be a fantastic game. I haven't had a chance to play the multiplayer or 2 yet, but considering this is the Homeworld 2 engine, I'm not going to assume much as changed since. Consensus: If you're interested in the game, then play it. It's a great game. But if you're looking to play the Homeworld 1 campaign, stick with the original. It's just... better. If they update this game, and patch it, then I'm sure it will be even better. Gearbox, you've done well, but wearing the skin of my girlfriend and trying to give me a kiss just isn't as appetizing as the real thing.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												This brings back memories. I absolutely love the remastered visuals and cleaned up audio. Some people are reporting bugs and glitches but I haven't really seen anything glaring out at me. One particular thing I could mention is when designating groups with multiple ship types the quantity numbering on the group selection to the lower left is difficult to read.I can see myself spending a huge amount of time with this collection. They did a lot of this out of passion and love for the original game. The developers were gamers themselves who want this to be a great rendition of a timeless classic, and you can tell they wanted this to have the soul of the original classics while being re-made for the modern system. The audio work alone merits a huge amount of praise but to see that they sensitively updated the visuals is also such a great bonus. You won't go wrong getting this. The most jaded and indifferent people will still be impressed by the quality of the arts presented by this collection. Great job Gearbox, this does a lot of goodwill towards bringing your reputation back into the good graces of gamers. I hope it sells like gangbusters.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												To start, if you have never played the original than you will probably like this game a lot more, this is the review of an old homeworld fanatic, and my complaints are mostly about infidelities to the originals. (Well the formation thing obviously needs fixing).I am very dissapointed with the remastered versions of these games. HW and HW2 handle formations and tactics very differently.  These mechanics could be reconciled, but aren't. Individual strikecraft built by kushan/taiidan do not stay in formation and tactics aren't as usefull (originally evasive ships were harder to hit and would spread on attacking, agressive ships would stay tight and fire as fast as possible). These features should be preserved, and the ui should simply adapt depending on what race you play, (taiidan/kushan get formations, hiigaran/vagyr strikegroups). If this was fixed I would be deeply satisfied. The graphics are wonderfully remastered and it has potentiall to be a brilliant rebirth of a personally treasured classic.I mostly just use this to play HW classic on my mac.PLEASE FIX THIS GAME

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												The game still stands as one of the greatest space opera ever made and now with a new coat of paint. A truly wonderful story about a race threatened with extinction looking for their Homeworld accompanied with unique atmosphere and daunting orchestral score. There are drawbacks to this remaster however including missing gameplay mechanics from the original such as physics simulated ballistics and relies on Homeworld 2's system of random number generator for combat simulation and while it has the original fleet formation coupled with the new ones the older ones tend to be bugged, alongside some pathing issues and missing fuel system, but those issues are due to remaking the original Homeworld in the Homeworld 2 some are certain to be fixed with patches while others can be addressed with re balancing. f you're new to Homeworld none of this should bother you as the RNG mechanics of Homeworld 2 are just as playable, as for the purists who prefer the original gameplay over the newer one, the collection has the original HW1 untouched and fully compatible with modern operating systems with the trade off of having antiquated graphics. Recommend it to anyone interested in space RTS games or a fantastic space saga in general. Truly one of the greatest games ever made and I can't be more excited for having this gem brought back to life instead of having it locked away in obscurity and intellectual property limbo.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												RE-TINKERED? Re-HASHED? In the music industry when a work is re-mastered, it generally means that technologies unnavailable at the time of the original recording are used to clear away the audio artifacts of an analog mastering process and hopefully present a truer version of the artist's work. In other words, it's "cleaned up" and will sound better than it ever has - especially on the new higher fidelity systems available.What Gearbox implies in their title is that they've done this with a game - whith higher resolution. Same work, by the same artists - just more enjoyable on modern systems.That's not what happened.What happened is more like a REMIX. The new artist can't help themselves and attempts to add to the original: to improve it or make it their own. And that's fine under two conditions:1. The new artist is honest about what's going on2. The new artist is talented enough to succeedNeither is the case here.What we have is a game that's somewhat better to look at, with a host of new bugs, newly broken mechanics, and at least one story breaking bug that stops progression several levels in and has you sitting there in deep space with nothing to do wishing it hand't cost you $34 dollars and many frustrating hours to get there. I wish I had avoided this one. But the allure of Relic's artistry was too great. If you are reading this and considering the purchase out of a nostalgic memory of what once was I'll say this: playing Gearbox's version of Homeworld is like going back to your home town after four years away at colledge. Many things are familiar, many are jarringly not, and the Home(world) you remember exists only in the past.It's too bad these hacks don't know their trade.RE-JECT this.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												For $35 one gets a game full of quirks and bugs. Unit behaviors and the balance of combat elements is changed substantially. It is confusing at first and then frustrating, as some of the most effective tactics (e.g. small units working in tight formation) can be ordered but don't actually happen. They would have done better to leave the game engine alone. The original Homeworld stands out as an all-time classic among 3D strategy/combat sims. I can only hope a few dollars got back to the original developers.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Even though I've not played these games for long so far, I can tell this is exactly what I wanted and was buying. Gearbox didn't dissapoint this time with this flawless remastering of a classic. These game's mechanics still hold up to this day and with updated graphics it leaves all other current RTS of this kind. It's very hard to describe the feeling you get when you combine nostalgia with a great game and then polish it to this level of sheen. This should be an instant purchase for past lovers of these games. Newcomers should also try these if they are fans of RTS games. The controls are smooth and intuitive. They work well for 3d navigation in 3d space. The HUD is relatively easy to navigate as well. My only complaint about the HUD is the upgrading and building menus. Those I have always considered somewhat clunky. Large scale space combat in these games is fun and cinematic. These games also feature a great soundtrack fit for space exploration. The added workshop compatibility for mods just makes this package too sweet to ignore. Can't wait for someone to redo Cataclysm and put it on there. All in all, a solid buy even at full price. It should be noted that I even dislike RTS games for the better part, but would place this game solidly on a top 10 games of all time list.

For me HW was always something special and the musical score done by Paul Ruskay only underline the whole experience with its orient-like flavour. Now with the remastered graphics and tweaked functions and mechanics Homeworld is truly worth your time.P.S.: Oh my god, it's so bloody good to fly the Big Banana again :)

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I first played this back in '99 and I was sorely impressed, I used to take the 100+ page manual (I miss those days) to read all over the place. It was the first game to get an actual emotional response out of me (that wasn't frustration), and you really felt for the protagonists for the story putting yourself right into their shoes (or that of S'jets).This remaster of such a beloved classic is incredible, and should probably be a benchmark by which other remasters compare themselves too. The improved graphics are rich with detail, and the audio (songs and dialog) is oh so much crisper now. it's not 100% perfect, but bug patches will surely fix things - or modders will. The fleet formations for HW1 strike craft don't quite work how they're supposed to which is a bit disappointing, and the enemy scaling between missions seems a bit overly harsh at times. There are a couple others such as black screens but I have not seen them yet. They also got rid of fuel which made me a little sad, since it reduces the need for resupply ships.Pro-tip; Steal everything that isn't nailed down. If it is nailed down, bring more salvagers. Also, don't overbuild your fleet. If you smash the enemy it might be wise to retire some strike craft before the next mission - otherwise you might find yourself in quite the pickle.

												Having played this for dozens and dozens of hours when I was younger, experiencing the Remastered Collection is an absolute treat. Everything has been upgraded, textures have more depth and polish, the ability to experience the games at higher resolutions brings out the beauty that was created so long ago, and the remastered soundtrack (one of the best ever in my opinion) adds a sense of scale and intensity to everything happening on screen. No more modern military shooters or the same racing games done countless times before, the Age of Space is back! And having one of the finest space RTS games ever, remastered for a whole new generation to experience solidifies itself as an absolute must own.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Now, I will make a note right now, I am a diehard Homeworld Fanboy. I played Homeworld 2 just a few months ago at the most recent. I also played Cataclysm fairly recently. However, Homeworld 1 eluded me after my childhood. You see, when I was 8, we got Homeworld 1 and I enjoyed it... that is, up until the asteroid mission where I could never get past it and never truely knew how the game evolved or even the ending.In fact, this, was the first time I have ever seen the ending of the original Homeworld.I loved it.It wasn't without its faults, but I couldn't really expect them to take a 15 year old game, ship it into a new engine, and fully remaster it without some issues being present. If you expected it to be perfect, you are a fool.They kept a lot of the basic gameplay elements that I remember while improving the bad things I forgot about. Here is a quick list of pros, cons, and bugs that I experienced.Bugs:Mission 3 broke for me on the first playthrough. I killed the frigates, but never got the objective to salvage the trays. Luckily it was a short mission and it was the only time I had to restart a mission. Might be worth checking out though.Pathing/AI seems to be extremely poor. The biggest issue I saw with this has an obvious answer too. Its the Homeworld 2 engine and that engine was not designed for single ships put into a chosen formation by the player. This causes OBVIOUS issues when you try to do it. Ships will immediatly drop out of their formations when combat starts and make no attempts to have any sembelence of sanity until the battle ends. Of course, this causes Homeworld 1 fighters to be damn near useless and you are way better off just running all frigates and capital class ships because they are useful past being cannon fodder... In most situations. On the Asteroid mission I got stuck on as a kid, I lost like 8 frigates to really terrible pathing which seemed to be caused by buggy asteroids. Pros:Homeworld is to this day considered the greatest designed space based RTS game ever created by a wide number of people. For good reason. This remastering brings the game into the current age of technology and holy♥♥♥♥♥♥did I just hear every other space based RTS♥♥♥♥♥♥themselves?Amazing Story that I finally got to enjoy fully for the first time in my life. I must say that the story telling in this game is a huge upturn to the current generation of games.Great gameplay mechanics for sure. The greatest being the persistent fleet between missions which can either make for an extremely fun situation or doomed to fail scenarios.Updated Graphics! This speaks for itself really.Updated Voice work!!!! This I was NOT expecting when I heard they would be remastering the game. They got the original voice actors and had them redo the lines with the higher quality recording technology and boy does it SHOW! If you watch the cutscenes from the original homeworld and compare it to these, you can not only see the difference in art, but you can HEAR the difference in voice acting too!Cons:Homeworld 2 Engine... I would have been WAY happier if they had used a different engine or maybe spent the time to make a new one. Perhaps one they could have used for Homeworld 3? ;) The Homeworld 2 engine is sloppy and actually causes the majority of the problems with the game as it sits. It was never that great, but I understand that it had to be done, it just makes me sad :(No difficulty setting - The best thing about Homeworld Cataclysm, was that at 8 years old you could set the difficulty to easy and blow through it and have fun with it. I had always wished a difficulty setting would have been in homeworld 1 so I could have beaten it as a kid and gotten way more enjoyment out of it. Now some other poor kid who might want to enjoy this game wont be able to either because it is too hard? Difficulty settings exsist so the player can choose their pace for the game and get the maximum enjoyment out of it. The point it was removed in Homeworld 2 and completely ignored still in this remastering simply reminds me of when I stopped bothering with homeworld 1 because I couldn't get past one mission. Then, by the time I was old enough to want to try again, it didn't work anymore on my computer. :'(

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Homeworld Remastered, is a good example of how a remaster should be.  This game consist of all the homeworld games to date (except for deserts of kharak).  If you're an RTS fan, this is a big must-have to any space fans and RTS fans out there.  Full 3D control, no constricted to the usual 2d plain that some space rts games have.  A long, challenging single player with lots of ways to finish them.  If you plan on playing the campaign, good luck, the difficulty in this game can go from easy to insane in a short time, mainly depends on how large your fleet is on later missions.Homeworld 1 Remake.  It has issues.  The biggest offended is the fact its just or feels more like a Homeworld 2 mod, but I guess its understandable, especially since they want all the races to be playable in skirmish or multiplayer, so they gotta keep them in the same engine.  The problem, a lot of HW1 features a missing.  So far they fixed some of them, mainly repair beams and I believe the harvesting.  All they need now is to brick back real time ballistics instead of an RNG chance system that homeworld 2 uses.  The other thing they need to fix is formations, luckily they're on the work for that, and the patch looks very promising.Homeworld 2 remake.  Since the remaster is using the HW2 engine, anyone who played the classic version already know how the gameplay is.  To the newcomers, homeworld 2 is the result when a developer is rushed to release a product, before release, the story was  to be much more larger (look up Homeworld 2: Dust Wars) however despite this, Homeworld 2 has one of the biggest or dedicated modding community out ther, check the workshop or the HW2 MODDB if you wanna see.  The things Homeworld 2 improved upon is the gameplay and obviously graphics (look at the classic HW1 and HW2, the difference in graphics is big) and the remaster just makes HW2 (and 1) a lot more beautiful.  Gameplay is good, its one of the best an RTS game offers, especially with its full 3D movement.  In a multiplayer match, you can send your units downwards (or upwards) towards the opposing fleet, and they'll never know whats coming to them (especially since we're so used to the usual 2D plain in RTS games)  The story is simple in the game yet emotional, especially since the Race you play as is almost extinct (spoilers)  Multiplayer is great too, even if you go against AI, its still a blast, because of the gameplay, you may find yourself too distracted looking at whatever your units are doing.tl;dr  Its a Must-have RTS game, buy it.+Great gameplay+Great soundtrack+Beautiful graphics+great sounds+good lengthy campaign +great modding community-HW1 features are missing-not a lot playing online (though it depends where you live and if you have good connection)-HW1 Remake feels more like a HW2 mod

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Having played this for dozens and dozens of hours when I was younger, experiencing the Remastered Collection is an absolute treat. Everything has been upgraded, textures have more depth and polish, the ability to experience the games at higher resolutions brings out the beauty that was created so long ago, and the remastered soundtrack (one of the best ever in my opinion) adds a sense of scale and intensity to everything happening on screen. No more modern military shooters or the same racing games done countless times before, the Age of Space is back! And having one of the finest space RTS games ever, remastered for a whole new generation to experience solidifies itself as an absolute must own.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I'm so happy! It's like my youth has been given back to me only better! Everything that was great about Homeworld and Homeworld 2 is still great, and now the visuals are appealing again too! The ships in this game sparked my imagination and forever influenced my perspective on science fiction engineering and now they look better than ever. The models are essentially the same but the textures are amazing and far more detailed than I ever would have expected. Properly normaled and bump-mapped, the Higaaran mothership finally looks like a giant industrial work. All of the fleet of both Higaaran and Vaygr ships are lovingly brought up to speed with modern machine capabilities. Even the HUD overlays are sharper and more clearly defined. The backdrops are gorgeous as ever and buffed to a fine polish with better lighting effects. In fact, all the graphical effects are much improved, from hyperspace windows to Kharaak burning from orbit, the game looks amazing now and the gameplay holds up after all this time.The cut-scenes are still impressively animated and mostly unchanged, although if my memory serves me the images are sharper and there are a few additional elements I don't remember, but the masterful voicework on both the narrated cuts as well as the idle radio chatter from your units still sucks me right back into the struggle to return the last of my people to my Homeworld.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Best space RTS ever. Period.  People whining about AI issues or other trivial things need to keep in mind that the remastered version was in development for less than a year - for $32(CAD)? That's a steal, considering most games these days are over $60.Are there bugs? Sure. Can they be fixed? Most likely. As in most cases, YMMV. I for one haven't experienced any major bugs. I believe the main focus for this remastered version was to improve the visual fidelity of game, not it's core mechanics - which are more or less the same, along with any issues the previous versions had.The important thing is that gearbox brought the game back in to existence, and didn't butcher it in the process.  Homeworld 3 now seems less like a pipe dream and more of a possibilty.Cheers.

Here is a quick list of pros, cons, and bugs that I experienced.Bugs:Mission 3 broke for me on the first playthrough. I killed the frigates, but never got the objective to salvage the trays. Luckily it was a short mission and it was the only time I had to restart a mission. Might be worth checking out though.Pathing/AI seems to be extremely poor. The biggest issue I saw with this has an obvious answer too. Its the Homeworld 2 engine and that engine was not designed for single ships put into a chosen formation by the player. This causes OBVIOUS issues when you try to do it. Ships will immediatly drop out of their formations when combat starts and make no attempts to have any sembelence of sanity until the battle ends. Of course, this causes Homeworld 1 fighters to be damn near useless and you are way better off just running all frigates and capital class ships because they are useful past being cannon fodder... In most situations. On the Asteroid mission I got stuck on as a kid, I lost like 8 frigates to really terrible pathing which seemed to be caused by buggy asteroids. Pros:Homeworld is to this day considered the greatest designed space based RTS game ever created by a wide number of people. For good reason. This remastering brings the game into the current age of technology and holy♥♥♥♥♥♥did I just hear every other space based RTS♥♥♥♥♥♥themselves?Amazing Story that I finally got to enjoy fully for the first time in my life. I must say that the story telling in this game is a huge upturn to the current generation of games.Great gameplay mechanics for sure. The greatest being the persistent fleet between missions which can either make for an extremely fun situation or doomed to fail scenarios.Updated Graphics! This speaks for itself really.Updated Voice work!!!! This I was NOT expecting when I heard they would be remastering the game. They got the original voice actors and had them redo the lines with the higher quality recording technology and boy does it SHOW! If you watch the cutscenes from the original homeworld and compare it to these, you can not only see the difference in art, but you can HEAR the difference in voice acting too!Cons:Homeworld 2 Engine... I would have been WAY happier if they had used a different engine or maybe spent the time to make a new one. Perhaps one they could have used for Homeworld 3? ;) The Homeworld 2 engine is sloppy and actually causes the majority of the problems with the game as it sits. It was never that great, but I understand that it had to be done, it just makes me sad :(No difficulty setting - The best thing about Homeworld Cataclysm, was that at 8 years old you could set the difficulty to easy and blow through it and have fun with it. I had always wished a difficulty setting would have been in homeworld 1 so I could have beaten it as a kid and gotten way more enjoyment out of it. Now some other poor kid who might want to enjoy this game wont be able to either because it is too hard? Difficulty settings exsist so the player can choose their pace for the game and get the maximum enjoyment out of it. The point it was removed in Homeworld 2 and completely ignored still in this remastering simply reminds me of when I stopped bothering with homeworld 1 because I couldn't get past one mission. Then, by the time I was old enough to want to try again, it didn't work anymore on my computer. :'(

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												To be fair, the HW1 remaster is kind of awful, since there are a bunch of gameplay issues created by dropping HW1 assets into the HW2 engine. Corvettes don't behave as they did in the original, you have to micro some things that didn't have to be microed before, a particular critical limitation of strike craft is gone, etc. That said, the original game was included, so you can play that instead. It's far from unplayable, so I went through it anyway to see the graphics and reexperience the plot.The HW2 remaster is beautiful, though. I spent more of my time replaying HW2 than HW1, so personally I would have been satisfied paying full price for only the HW2 remaster and nothing else. Full mod support has been promised, and we have it from the head of the Complex mod that they've done a good job on that front. I liked 2's gameplay better; some people liked 1 better. Probably a lot of these issues will be addressed in the coming days - the problems with the HW1 remaster seem correctable, and the modding community should have a good time.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												A Great remaster of an RTS classic 9 out of 10 [Was an 8.5] So far I have run into only one bug and mostly it is just a random annoying Crash to desktop when a mission loads first time in HW1 and I am not even sure it is the game all of my games have been crashing randomly since the last steam client update.[Addendum: Found a hot fix for the CTD I have been having reducing texture size stops the crash however for some reason all my saves from yesterday are broken so I had to restart I am assuming this was caused by an update of some kind]I can't speak for bugs other people have had but most of them seem fairly minor and avoidable (ie. compleating an objective before it is assigned makes it impossible to beat the mission without reloading). Save often so that a crash/bug won't hurt as bad (besides the HW games get HARD so saving helps a lot even if you never run into a bug).As for improvements from the classic games HW1 basically now uses the HW2 UI, it feels like some things have been rebalenced so it no longer is as unforgiving as the original, and of course the graphics are insanely good seriously watching the ships fly around is half the fun. Also thank Fraking god they made it so you collect all of the maps rescorces at the end of a mission extra .5 to score for that. [Some people have been complaining about this fix but the whole you have to collect everything in HW1 was anoying it didn't make the game more difficult it made it tedious and unfriendly to new players.]Oh and did I mention you get the classic versions of HW1 and HW2 so if worse comes to worse and your rig can't play the remaster you can always boot up the original.A few problems I have with the game- salvagers now need massive micro managing.- Formations only hold for the first few seconds of combat - The alternate mothership design/ unit designs from the original were removed this annoys me because I like them better than the ones used in this game.- The credit song from the original is gone (I suspect there were rights issues which is why I am not to angry but still...)If you are into RTS games buy this.(Note: I will update this as I play if I run into anything major.)

I can only hope a few dollars got back to the original developers.

												I remember playing the old school Homeworld...I was 15...damn I feel old.Anyway, I couldn't fully appreciate it back then. For me it was just 'pew pew...splosions!" Granted, compared to most RTS games coming out today, it's punishingly difficult. It doesn't hold your hand, but growing up on Atari and Nintendo, without the joy of save files and regenerating health, I was used to it. It was and still is one of my favorite RTS games (perhaps my favorite). If grew up with this game, it'll feel like home. If you're like me, your jaw will probably drop when you see the facelift it's gotten. It's absolutely beautiful. The space battles are as intense as ever. And remastered, the laser heavy dog fights and resulting explosions is some of the most satisfying gaming you'll experience all year. Go watch the PAX demonstration if you need further proof. Let me just mention one more thing. Mission 3 of Homeworld 1...the music combined with the imagery...it's goosebump inducing. Don't go look it up and ruin it for yourself. It's something you need to experience free of spoilers. It'll be on your top ten list of best gaming moments, trust me. This is a no brainer, in my opinion. If you loved Homeworld 1 and 2 in their original forms then this will be like revisiting an old friend from high school that got really really hot and now wants to sleep with you. If you didn't play this game back in the day, but you love the RTS genre, it's a no brainer. This is one of the finest entries in the genre and it now looks as good as anything else on the market.For all of you with older machines, this is really well optimized. So if you've got a laptop or perhaps a couple year old gaming rig, don't worry too much, it should be fine.

												First off, I was a huge HW fan back when I was a kid in High School so I'll be as fair as I can in the review thus far.  After a good amount of time into missions in both HW and HW2 I can say that it is not without bugs.  There is a few frustrating ones where even if you do too well in a objective you bug the game! lol  Besides the bugs that make you redo a mission it's not that big of a deal, save often and even if you don't the game auto saves for you.  The visuals are amazing and the sole reason I bought the game, I wanted to replay this wonderful game and see it in updated graphics and play with some friends from HS.  The multiplayer is still in beta as they just started writing the code on it and are having to work out the kinks.  Be patient as you can still get in games with friends and others but sometimes you get a out of sync error when you start or some other frustrating issue.  Overall I will say the game is great especially if you never played HW you should hands down if you like any sort of RTS or space strategy games.  The storyline is fun and is overall a great experience.  Thank you for redoing this masterpiece of a game and I hope you continue to work out the multiplayer bugs, but I'm going to say you should've fixed them before it was released.  Gamers can be patient but not when they get bugs in a game that was already a hit.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												It's really great to play this game again, especially because of the lack of good RTS games these days. At the price it is, it's really a steal as you get 4 games included (the original games and the remastered games). I still maintain that this is one of the greatest games ever made.However I do have a few of gripes.There are a few bugs and a few instabilities. The game crashes at the moment in multiplayer, which is seriously dodgy and shoddily made anyway. Sure it does say beta - but you'd expect glaring bugs like crashing when you connect to a game and not being able to connect to people's games, even through steam, who are in different regions than you, (unless you change your download location in Steam, but why should you have to?) to be fixed before release, or at the very least shortly after (been 3 days now without a single patch).Another thing is that this game has been "remastered". That's great and some things have been greatly improved. BUT it still looks really old. The skins and effects have been updated, aswell as some of the sounds, mostly for the better but sometimes for the worse. Example: interceptor/scout guns used to sound great in the original; kind of like machineguns, while in the remake they LITERALLY go "pew pew pew".Also when a game is remastered, you'd expect them to at least update the AI a bit. The battlecruisers in HW2 are STILL majorly bugged in that they simply cannot fly forward without a major headache, usually spinning around and around, very very slowly, reminding me of when I used to play homeworld 2 back in the day and never used BCs for this very reason. Ships also fly out of formation and kamikaze with harmful asteroids in a certain mission in the first game.My biggest gripe is that the Taiidan and colour options are missing from the Homeworld campaign. In the original, you could pick from two different fleet styles and colour them however you wanted. Now you are basically shoved into the game with none of those options, really proving some of us purists right when we were worried about gameplay being changed.In multiplayer they have merged the fleet styles from both the first and second game. I need to play some more but I can't help thinking that they are highly incompatible.Don't get me wrong this is a great game and still well worth your cash. I will summarise thusly:Homeworld Remastered is a great game but the remastered part is very misleading. Some key gameplay options have been changed, others removed completely. The skins and effects have been upgraded but the models themselves look old and blocky still. The AI has NOT been remastered at all, not even a little bit, and the whole thing just feels... lazy. Still an amazing deal but only because it's riding on the success of the original masterpiece from Relic. Definately worth it, but it could have been even better with a little more effort in the right places.Postscript: Please get rid of that horrible bloody hyperspace icon that obnoxiously pastes itself on the screen at the end of a mission.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												I would recomend with caution. the games cost is 40$ at the current time and there are some  BUGs i am getting black screens that i can still scroll but can't see nothing just hear the battle right after the cut screens after cut sceens if you try to skip them. (after playing some more i have figured out that the esc key can crash the game if you use it to close windows and cancel orders too much, i had the map view open and the mothership building menu opened and used esc to close and the back ground faded out to black all i had left was the overlay and sound and the game still working but i can't see nothing.) but you can save your game when this happens and reload it and it will have the picture back on the screen where you left off.Also if doesn't explain very much so if you have not played before and are use to being spoon fed with tutorials explaining every detail then you might get overwhelmed at times.   Here are a few things about homeworld 1 that don't fit.  The controls are odd the UI is well... seems unfinished.  The ESC key doesn't bring up the option menu which is in most games so it becomes comfusings at times. There is no mouse sensitivity for the zoom or side scroll  so you miss the battle.  The formations fall apart once in battle. After playing around  for many hours you can get the hang of it.That being said I am still having fun with this game and recommend it if you don't mind wating for some patches because i am sure they will fix the major issues.  This was a  rushed review to get it out there so don't use this to make up your mind on what could be a great exprience.My rating so far is 7/10 gaming breaking bugs. This is more like a Homeworld2 pre-qual instead of Homeworld.Not to be hard on the game but you don't need me to tell you about the pros you can read about those on other reviews

												Seems like a hugely ambitious project, but aggravatingly counterintuitive interface ruins the entire experience for me. After couple of hours struggling against it I gave up. Perhaps if the game didn't rip away my already feenle as they are controls from me for the sake of showing me something obvious and holding me tied there for no apparent purpose or reason while my units are being cheerfully slaughtered in another spot of the map where I'll spend a full minute getting to once the game decides to release me... You get the picture. If you are used to controls of every other big RTS title out there and expect the interface to be half as intuitive and sensible as them - you are in for a struggle. If you feel like spending your time learning from scratch an entirely new arbitrarily keyed method of orienting yourself in space in real time for a few hours before you even get to the actual gaming - well, then you might actually write a better review. Good luck.

												Too many bugs, do not buy until they fix. Unless you're just after homeworld original on steam. Homeworld 2 sucked and still sucks, so I have no comments on that. My review is based on trying to play Homeworld remastered. Multiplayer is a cluster♥♥♥♥ also, but they labled it beta and the plan is to work on balance I guess?Pros:- New GraphicsCons:- Formations don't work properly, which ties in with aggresive and defensive maneuvers not working properly (these 4 top points are all related and contribute to fighters and corvettes being worthless, besides salvage and repair)- Fighers die too easy- Fights hardly do any damage- Fighters (and any unit for that matter) forget orders randomly and do what ever they feel like.- Mission triggers randomly break, you might not know that you're mission is bugged until you're "finished but the next trigger won't trigger because you somehow broke it earlier, meaning you have to start the mission again...- Certain ships don't work like they used to making them worthless, like the support frigate was able to heal ships from a distance and now does nothing...- Adjusting missions according to your fleet, dosen't seem to be balanced right (but also has to do with a lot of other issues of stuff not working properly, which makes everything hard- The Garden of Kadesh used to be a hard mission, even though it's only fighters you fight. Now they seem to be broken and not working properly making it so easy you hardly do anythingIf you're looking to play Homeworld, wait until a sale to get it. If you're looking to play homeworld remastered, wait until it's patched and works. If you're looking to play homeworld 2, IDK ask someone else. It's probably functioning as normal though. And multiplayer is un-balanced as hell at the moment.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Brilliant remake of a classic game, a few small bugs, nothing that stop you playing, a few changes some good some not so good depending on your taste, for exsample the battlecruisers can no longer have extra missile or beam upgrade, 2 slots have been removed.The explosions have been completely re-done and look absolutely awesome now, and also leave alot of salvageable material too.The game has all of its original controls, which is excellent.There are a couple of new factions/enemies some new ships, all with the same style as the original homeworld 2 ships, very neatly done indeed.Mods lack a bit of support still, half of them work half of them dont.One mod COMPLEX 9 works great and allows for the unit cap, which is still around the same as HW2 original, to be lifted to extraordinary levels, example 90 odd capitol ships, much much fun if you have a beefy PC like I do.Definately worth the 34$ steam are charging for the re-mastered version, if you like HM2 original, you are going to love this very fresh and invigorating remake of a classic game.It would be great if there was a map editor like ''skunks map editor'' for HW2 re-mastered..., The ability to create your own maps is the one big thing they should have put into the game as a standard feature that they missed.   Maybe in a future patch perhaps.....Now I have fleets to cull ! Bye !

content:
Posted: January 13
												““So, I bought this game during the winter sale and like many other mainly single player games I own, I assumed that I would play for a couple hours and then put the game down because I didn't want to grind my way through the story. Tomb Raider was different. This campaign is one of the most exciting campaigns I have played in years, and that puts this game on my all time favorites list with great games like Star Wars: Battlefront (2004), and Halo Reach. I could not put this game down. Around every corner there is something to fine. Unfortunately, I grinded the games story and managed to complete the story with an overall game completion of 68%, but there is no doubt in my mind that I will not play this game again soon. I played the game on the hardest dificulty, and although I died a couple times - seven times to be exact - The game was so much fun that I didn't care about me dying when I got rushed by 20 autoaiming enemies. Overall, I love this game. I found everything about it great: the story, the graphics, and gameplay. It isn't often that I find a game like this where I want to come back and keep playing day after day, and not put it down at all. This game is amazing.””

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												When I picked up a dusty copy of Homeworld, some years after its release, and booted up this obscure 3D Space RTS, and its equally beautiful sequel, Homeworld 2, I could never have imagined that now, perhaps a Decade later,  they would once again return to my computer screen, reimagined in glorious HD.The story is powerful, at times desperate, but ultimately rewarding. The narrative is genuine, sorrowful, the voice of Fleet Command falters at the sight of the Genocide of Kharak, pilots mourn and seek revenge with rabid determination. This gives way in turn to triumpthant relief. Ships catch the light of exotic Nebulae, projectiles and lasers cast fiery arcs on their hulls. The graphical direction becomes another dimension to the story, everything is just Human enough for the gamer to be totally immersed in the struggle, the exiles clinging to hope in these ships almost becoming your own people.This re-release of Homeworld and Homeworld 2, is a fitting homage to the genius of this series. Many an hour will be lost, or invested, in joining these weary exiles on their slow, tortured, hazard filled journey to that place we all hope to find, home.10/10

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												This is a biased review - let's get that out of the way early.Having played the three originals, and having kept an eye on the progress of the remasters, it's fair to say that I was a fan before release, and one of those 'old guys' who eagerly awaited this arrival with crossed fingers and a daily prayer to the gaming gods for Gearbox not to screw it up. Was it going to be a labour of love, a cash-in, a botch job? I was understandably concerned.Straight out of the gate, there's a clue. When the opening titles splash, and it's introduced as a remastering of a game by Relic first and foremost, you realise that these guys are paying due deference to the source. I knew this already, as Gearbox have gone out of their way to collect original voice actors, and even original design team members to give this the attention it needs. They spent time putting everything in place to reproduce a classic. More than that, what originally started out as a simple release with a HD upgrade turned into a full-on remaster with not just improved visuals, but high fidelity sound. Gearbox had the chance to make this a cash grab. They passed up that chance of merely cleaning the windows and elected to give it a full service, respray, a new set of tyres, and replaced the engine while they were there. Sadly for some, they did mess with the handling a little, but I'll get to that.Whenever I load up the originals, while they're still excellent in gameplay, the visuals are suffering. They don't look like how I remember them. There appears to be some gap between reality and my imagination. My imagination upgrades visuals as I go along, and I'm invariably disappointed  when I find that my memory is lying to me and the games have a lower resolution than my imagination does. Original HW2 still looked pretty good, but HW1 was showing its age badly. Apparently Gearbox thought the same. The remastered versions look like how I imagine the originals. They look better.They're beautiful.Nebulae are rich and vibrant, with that otherworldly quality that makes space look much more lovely than it is. Ships are detailed, explosions are impressive and Kharak and Hiigara have never looked so amazing. In one sweeping moment, all the graphical issues that come with decades old games - gone.So far so good. How's the gameplay though?Gearbox have modified HW1's gameplay to be more like HW2. This will be sacrilege for some, and for those who thought HW2 improved a lot of things, it will seem as simply sensible.Fighter formations are no longer entirely static. They hold formation until they engage the enemy, and then as one would expect, they break off into one almighty hairball with contrails zipping in and out of each other to the incongruous tune of vacuum explosions. This seems more realistic (minus the forgivable space sound), and yet it unarguably removes a facet of the original that some will find hard to bear.Some won't like it. I realise that, and I think Gearbox did too. They telegraphed it ahead of release to ease fans into the idea. Time will tell if Gearbox patch this feature back in. Also, the fuel mechanic is gone. Can't say I lament its passing. It was tedious.Other than that, Gearbox have kept a very light touch, and have changed very little. They clearly know not to mess with a proven title too much. There are good reasons for the changes they did make however. To allow a seamless transition from the first to the second game, one of them would have to change as there were some significant differences. You can literally play them back to back now, and they feel like you're playing the same game. Nothing jars. Also, the UI is standard across the two. It's now even more minimalist than it used to be, allowing you more screen real-estate to watch the carnage. It doesn't take long to navigate your way round, and in no time at all you'll find yourself hotkeying your way to victory.Other than that, Gearbox have left the gameplay largely untouched, which is interesting. They must have been tempted to 'do a Lucas', but they didn't. What's even more interesting is that the gameplay from two titles which are now 16 and 12 years old respectively, doesn't suffer by modern standards. They're perfectly fine. I'm not sure of any other genre that could make that boast, but then, there really hasn't been much like Homeworld since.People still compare it to its nearest contemporary, Sins of a Solar Empire, and that is telling. Sins is nothing like Homeworld. Both are set in space, and both are viewed from a god's eye view, and that's it. Of course, for those who simply cannot stand the few changes that have been made, Gearbox included the two originals as well, with some fixes to enable them to run on modern machines.There are some bugs. I've had a couple of crashes and there appears to be a persistent engine audio bug that is banished by opening the game menu. Others report more bugs than I've seen, so hopefully Gearbox will get on the case and tweak a little.All in all, for the price, you cannot go wrong. Two games, two versions of each. One for the more strident hard-like fans, and an updated version for everyone else that is simply a joy to play. All for the price of one game. I was starting to fear these games would be lost to the history bin, but thanks to Gearbox I've managed to walk with the Kushan once more on their cosmic caravan to regain their Homeworld, and also with the newly renamed Hiigarans, striving against overwhelming odds to preserve it. It was as much a pleasure this time round as the first.Hopefully, now that HW1 and 2 are accessible once more to the gaming public, Gearbox will move on from here to Homeworld 3, and Shipbreakers, the latter of which is already well into development. After playing through the beautiful Remastered games, I'll be waiting eagerly.For those who have never played these games, fair warning, they may seem harder than modern gamers are accustomed to, but they're as brilliant now as they were originally, and even though it's a much overused cliche, they deserve a place on any gamer's digital shelf.Now, back to killing those Taiidani and Vaygr scum ...

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I played the original Homeworld for days on end and hoped by the infos released, it would be a remarkable bundle of glorious HD childhood remembrance. I was wrong.One of the main reasons I didn't really play and / or like Homeworld 2 was related to fleets. Yes, one of the main things elevating this game from other RTS was bothering me. Why? The AI didn't have a fixed fleet (size) like in HW1, but instead was composed of units perfectly cancelling out your whole fleet. You captured Frigates, Destroyers, Cruisers only to get them destroyed by counter-units spawned exactly for this ship. In HW1 you had a unique fleet consisting of Kadeshi, Turanic and Taiidan ships mixed with your run-off-the-mill standard units. It was simply put beautiful. They kept their original paint job and most of them performed extraordinarily. You cared deeply for your units because you couldn't build new ones to replace them, because they were unique. If you built units, it was mostly supporters and / or special ships. Why? Because resources were scarce and had to be consolidated around the necessities. You used what you had carefully and many a time you had to reload a game because you lost one too many ship or one dear to you.Then, in HW2, you had this urge to capture cool Vaygr craft like missile frigates. Boy was I proud to finally have captured a few of those. Then I harvested resources the old fashioned way and prepared a fleet to be able to counter everything I thought could be thrown at me. In the next mission I was always surprised to find the enemy being able to kill every last one of my ships at will, because his fleet strength was measured exactly by mine. This made me realize that capturing and keeping special or even more useful ships than mine was futile. I had to scrap every single one of them just to not be overrun and lose them in the next mission. After one or two missions I came to the conclusion that I had to scrap all ships excluding ship production vessels if i didn't want a mass extinction to happen. My fleet at the end and start of each mission basically was a Chinese sweat shop.This moved me farther and farther away from caring just the tiniest bit for my fleet - because why would I? Everything was interchangeable or could be rebuilt. It was always the same. Scrap and rebuild. Scrap and rebuild. At some point I just produced ships to counter the enemy, not to have an effective fleet. The ones built faster were in higher numbers than the rest, because who gives a♥♥♥♥♥♥ right? They will be scrapped either way. I realized that this was not the type of game I was expecting a HW game to be and abandoned HW2 for good. Now they made this gorgeous looking game and based it on the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI fleet mechanism that HW2 had. I feel betrayed because the previews don't talk about that and just blow sugar up its♥♥♥♥♥ They removed many functions like the support frigates' repair beam or group capture with salvettes. It's a nightmare of micro management wrapped in gorgeous HD graphics. I will NOT play the campaigns of either of them because it just pisses on my childhood memories of HW1. Too many things are wrong with the game and I will wait until they address it. The forums are aflame because of the same reasons.I even bought the CE because I was so sure it would live up to the original. At the moment it's nothing more than a HW1 mod for HW2 with better graphics. The formations are broken, the launch manager is a mess, research costs money, the "z"-with-selection-rectangle functions are missing altogether, the AI fleets are dynamically generated based on your fleet.I liked the serenity of the old HW1. You had your objective, completed it and collected resources while getting your fleet ready for the next mission. You built ships, organized groups or just watched your harvesters do their work. The new games focus more on massive battles - which are literally pre-programmed - and watch all you built up explode and scatter just to win by  a hair.If you liked the "Transformers" movies, this one is for you. If you liked the original HW game, you should wait.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Homeworld 1s gameplay was ditched in favor of Homeworld 2s. Units are still singular, but they behave and attack like the ones in the second game... that means even in defensive mode, my units were wandering far away from the mothership. The formations also don't work, putting units in the sphere mode and then setting them to guard something doesn't make them form the sphere around the thing they're guarding, nor split up when defending several individual units. The scout and interceptor weapon projectiles are not a hail of bullets, now its a steady but noticably slower stream of bolts. Fuel is totally gone. Salvage units can capture fighters now because it does a premade animation rather than fly at the target until its close enough, furthermore it lost the graphic on its capture nodes. These are only a few of the irritating changes, it's just not fun this way. I wouldn't recommend playing this legally.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												Homeworld is not a bad RTS it's just very overrated. Homeworld was a little before I got into RTS's so I had never played it. But everytime I ever asked my friends what they thought was the best RTS of all time, Homeworld always made someones top or atleast top 3. They would go on and on as to why it was such a great RTS and why todays RTS's will never be as good. So when Homeworld remastered came out I jumped at the chance to check out what all the excitment was about. After playing for a while I found my self very underwhelmed and disappointed. Maybe it was because my expectations were unrealistic but nothing was what I had expected. The game had some interesting RST elements but the combat was extremely slow and this is coming from someone who enjoyed the Civilizations and Total War games. The story the worst disappointment of all. I have no idea why so many people say the story was good, the game barely even had one.  All of that being said it's still not a bad RTS my pros and cons below with my personal rating at the end. Pros:Interested rst elementsGreat sound trackLots of strategy decent graphics decent UICons:Awful storyExtremely slow-pacedrobotic voice actinguninteresting combat 6.5 out of 10 While not bad, the game has extremely slow paced combat that few would enjoy.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												Wow, this game has not aged well at all. Do you remember what it was like to play an RTS back in 1999? It feels like this: very poor unit readability, a right-click that willfully misunderstands you, units that default to "ignore enemies", spellcasters with no auto-cast... this game is just full of weird awkward design. Sound fun? Here's what you'll be doing half the time: squinting at a screen of dots, frantically hovering over them to figure out which tiny dot is the dot that will do some small ineffectual ability, and then figuring out how to get that dot to target another dot out of 100 dots.This is a golden age of real-time strategy. They have unparalleled accessibility and visibility, more than any other time in history... and this is an RTS about HUGE 3D SPACES that doesn't let you use WASD to navigate it? Yikes yikes yikes.The Foss-inspired ship designs and Adagio for Strings are still there, and perfectly lovely.But if you're honest with yourself, this game is surprisingly unpleasant to play. "Remastering" implies they've looked at RTS design within the last 15 years, and incorporated modern accessibility into the interface. They're hoping you're so nostalgic that you overlook their laziness. Maybe that's OK, maybe Gearbox really needed some quick revenue and this was a fairly sure bet, fair enough.In doing so, they commit the worst crime in AAA -- they feel cheap.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												I played the old Homeworld 2 and instantly fell in love, this new iteration is no exception. Everything from the graphics to the controls are crisp and wonderful to behold. I have played all sorts of RTS games from Age of Empires to Civ 5 to Star Wars Empire at War. However, this game keeps your attention better than any of them I feel. That constant fear of an attack from above or below, as the 3D plane allows, keeps you on your toes. There are always more layers to this game so that you will never get bored, and if you somehow do, it allows mods! Hardcore RTS players will enjoy the depth of strategy and casual players, like myself will also find this to be quite enjoyable. 10/10

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												By the gods, this is amazing on so many levels.Some time ago, when Homeworld was first launched, I remember people commenting about it being a Masterpiece. I doubted, so I bought the game. I remember the last time I played the campaing, it was the 14th time I did it. Then, Homeworld 2 came. I played it so many times or more, not to mention the mods. Then the games disappeared. I was hoping that someday they would pop on Steam, but I was almost giving up.Until now.I think that there is no game that I've waited more than HW Remastered. When I heard that it was Gearbox who was remastering it, I was unsure of the quality of the work. Now I can die peacefully: the masterpiece is back. Remastered.A quick tech overview:-The graphics are amazing, but incredibly faithful to the original. The new models are so close to the original ones that they can fulfill their purpose: be what our "mind's eye" saw when we first played it. New effects, revamped textures and lightning only add to the nearly divine aspect of the game.-The music... when I first heard the choir, I cried like a baby, Ultra high quality true to the modern-day standards. And the subtitles. If you like them, they are there with a charisma of their own.-The gameplay... I played the tutorial to see if I was rusty. I was. But the controls did not change much. The UI is clean, with a deep degree of fidelity to HW2's UI. Smart move, as some are saying.Veredict:Masterpiece.11/10, worth every cent.PS: If any of you are wondering, they did not include the original pdf files in the package. I managed to find the Historical Briefing, you can find it here: http://www.homeworldaccess.net/downloads/hw1docs/HistoricalandTechnicalBriefing.pdfUpdate - 10/27/2015They have fixed a lot of errors, and it seems they're still working on it. Formations will not work as they did in HW1, but that's because the games were created based on the HW2 engine (which do not have the same formations). It is true that they add a deeper layer of strategy to the game, but their absence is not catastrophic, but rather a matter of re-learning the game. Still recommended.

Posted: February 25, 2015
												10/10, no question about itGearbox really outdid themselves and remade this classic with love and care, and boy does it show. Everything from the textures and models to the audio and soundtrack has been recreated with special attention to detail. It looks absolutely unbelievable, literally jaw dropping. Not to mention, it's optimized beautifully. My computer is not a gaming laptop, only running a NVIDIA Geforce 750m. Yet even on the medium settings, this game runs at a very smooth framerate. And the medium and lower settings still look fantastic.I could go on, but if you're reading this, just go buy Homeworld Remastered Collection already. You're truly missing out if you don't.

content:
Posted: April 17
												I am baffled to say the least. The game(s), upon startup of a level/mission/game/etc... freezes and crashes after merely a few seconds, IF I can get into a game at all. See that 24 minutes I spent in this game? Only 2 of those were me actually doing something, the rest was me starting up the game, only to have it crash at the title screen, or not even make it there, but only to the Gearbox logo or somewhere between. This was an absoulute waste of 34.99$, and I'm happily going to point you away from this "game," or more so, "Crashing Simulator,"

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20
												It's very unfortunate that the gameplay of Homeworld 1 was butchered like this. Pretty graphics do not make up for losing the immersion of being a tactical-commander & ordering wings to attack in formation  aggressively or evasively. Nor does it make up for the eye-candy of following the action with your camera and watching ballistically-realistic shots hit enemies and miss your ships. The many ways this faux remaster has screwed with the game leaves me bitter.Even so, it's hard not to recommend this game, especially for people who haven't played it & refuse to touch the original with its dated graphics. Yet I still do not recommend you advocate such soulless practices.Video games are unregulated for the most part. Player, it is your voice & actions that regulates what the industry should & shouldn't do. Think before you buy.

number of helpful: 2 of 10 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												I played the entire first game and a large chunk of the second one and I simply don't understand it. I consider myself a strategy game nerd, but my only major difficulty in playing these games was getting my spaceships to fly how I wanted them to. The enemy never put pressure on me, and I felt no need to keep them on the defensive or have any other strategic consideration whatsoever. My resources weren't scarce at all, and I selected the default difficulty. I cannot be bothered to replay these lessons in boredom on another difficulty level. The ships all functioned roughly the same, with the exception of the carrier. Amazing tedium compounded by a pace of storyline and action that can only be described as brooding.
