content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												Good news: The graphics look great. Unfortunately they forgot to make the game fun.They hired some bottom-of-the-barrel unemployed mobile game devs to go and forget 20 years of user interface design and make all new mistakes while solving problems that didn't exist.All of the combat feeling that made Catacylsm fun is gone and they went all-in on the un-fun that was Homeworld 2. Combat feels slow. Simply moving a unit requires two clicks, because "Are you sure you want to do that?".There is no use in detailing all the tiny things they got wrong. They just shipped an unfinished re-publishing of an old game because things got hard and dumb mobile devs can't fix bugs because they don't understand the basics of user interface design.

content:

												As it is now I HATE it.Sorry, but where is splendid fighter micro from oryginal series? Now formations are only for looks before combat, when fighting starts they're gone. Sphere formation - basics for defending is gone.Silly bugs that could be avoided if someone played a game. Example? You press B key for build menu. Easy eh? But you can't close it with B when you're done with it. Suprisingly it works with Research menu (R), and doesn't work again for Launch menu (L). And there is more.Another example. Mission (i think) 4, u can capture 3 destroyers. When you do, 1 gets to keep oryginal imperial paintjob, other 2 r recoloured as kushan. Not nuff testing, rushed game.Edit: It's mission 9 and now all 3 r painted Kushan :D It's like back in school, when you don't look someone will paint♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on your stuff :DDozens of these.Also game treats u like a moron, giving you unfair advantage against cpu, adjusting damage or armor according to some sort of learning curve? Dunno yet. Self healing is crazy.I had these 2 destroyers firing at each other for 10 minuts.I mean 10 bloody minutes!2 destroyers! And they can't die!Missiles suck too, before they ripped fighters apart. Now they r shiney.BolloxI mean there r improvements, but I also think that it's not HW anymore. And also - it's NOT FINISHED. Why didn't you offer an open beta? or closed beta? Why not hear from community?Well there is one obvious answer - community would not approve some of concepts Gearbox made, and I think they knew that.And if you think patches, opinions will make this game better. They will not - ofc silly bugs will be fixed, like the ones I mentioned above. But game concept was decided before programmers started coding, and things that made oryginal HW - HW are simply gone. Now it's... pimped HW2 pretending to be something it isn't.Oh, also sound sucks too. There are no more emotions there :(

												Love Homeworld, me not recommending the game is not a reflection of it, but on the state of its release.Gearbox, did you even test this before release? There are bugs that are there simply by playing normally, nothing that needs to be found by a variety of circumstances happening all at once that would be easily missed until in the hands of many. I know I'll probably be ignored or downvoted, whatever. You know I'm right, this game is bug ridden all to hell. Tutorial continues without hitting"OK", ships getting stuck on objects, scripting failing to initiate, formations breaking up in HW1, sound glitches, UI problems.Dont' support this release, it's blatantly obvious Gearbox did not adequately playtest this, probably because they knew it'd sell bucketloads anyway. I'd say wait a month or two to see if Gearbox stands by their product that they proclaim so much to admire and patches this to what it should've been on release.Shame.

number of helpful: 0 of 7 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												i can't believe people are still talking about this. how did people ignore the fact that this is suppose to be a Battlestar Galactica game? granted it does retell nicely from the original BSG, but in the end, its a colossial dissapointment for me. first the positives, The Graphics are amazing (both the original and the remasted version), the ship designs are awesome (particularly the Taiidan, the Hiigarans and the Vaygr), the gameplay is addicting and the soundtrack fanfreakingtastic! the mods are wonderful for both classic HW2 and HWR, two of my faves are Cataclysm Remasted and Brickspace (though as of now, CR is still in dev and wished it would have been the official sequel to the first homeworld). but the voice acting's so bad they all sound like robots, intentional or not (with the exception of the late Cambell Lane as both the Bentusi and the Narrator), and the pacing is about as well as a snail on molasses. and what's worse is that its official sequel while technically better then the first one, its storywise worse, with lots of cliches, plot holes etc as far as i checked. and even more worse is that a prequel(/Sequel) will come out next month that takes place before and after HW2? What? NO!! don't make both a prequel and a sequel at once, it makes no sense!! at least with a remake/sequel it starts off like the same, but eventually follows up afterwards like in Evil dead II. here, this is just dumb! why did you let Gearbox by your IP, Blackbird?! i recommand it just for the gameplay, visuals, music and mods alone. otherwise i will never recommand it just for the story alone.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Never played Homeworld, or even heard of it.I always was a fan of RTSes and tried this one out.Of course it is a remastered version so I'm probably critiquing old game mechanics that was simply enhanced graphics-wise. In any case, but I can't say I'd recommend it to anyone.Every mission is basically built around the concept of 1. Build fleet2. Lose majority of fleet3. Repeat steps 1 and 2.This is if you get everything right.Also, you'll need repeat the mission one or two+ times.The reason is that you have to build the right ships that counter the enemy ships WAY beforehand, because you have only one production building ship and you cannot build anymore of them. If the enemy fleet is coming and  you start building the CORRECT ships to beat them, they won't be out in time. It can only build 2 units at the same time and if it is the same unit, then this feature doesn't work. It has to be two different units.The story is intriguing to say the least. However, the gameplay insight is very lacking.

number of helpful: 3 of 15 people (20%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												Really enjoyed the remastered versions but it's clear the better in terms of gameplay is in Homeworld 2 Remastered. This is where it's at, this is where most of the fun and enjoyment from Remastered comes from: Homeworld 2 Remastered.The game looks really nice and on par with just about any RTS out there in terms of beautiful graphics plus the requirements are very low all considered. There are bugs but not any game breaking bugs. For some reason Homeworld 2 Classic won't run for me at all but everything else will... Still, should be fixed next patch it hopefully.Multiplayer is a lot of fun allowing you to host either Homeworld 1 Deathmatch rules, Homeworld 2 Deathmatch or Homeworld Remastered rules with a lot of match options in size of the map, resources, relic spawns, etc. It is in beta and extremely buggy with a lot of crashes when loading matches at the moment but this seems to be tied with mods available on STEAMWorkshop that effect multiplayer. This will hopefully be more stable when patched.Definitely worth the price. Game looks amazing, runs really well and you get the original games(You can't get them anywhere else at the moment) plus the two remastered versions and a unified multiplayer client. Well worth every single penny.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
												Playing Homeworld is a great way to switch off and indulge in an evening of forgettable relaxation. The colourful space vistas, twisting neon engine trails, and soft explosions all come together to create a dreamy feel – which is just as well given how soporific the gameplay is.Like other space RTS games, Homeworld removes the genre staple of terrain but provides nothing to replace it. Your activities will be managing bog standard rock/paper/scissors unit counters while gathering a single resource type. 3D movement is one of the USPs but it adds very little: in the vacuum it's just a slightly more fiddly movement direction, albeit one which grants your ships an arbitrary damage bonus to targets above or below their own plane.The most you'll need to think about 3D movement is when positioning capital ships, most of which can only fire in front of them and all of which turn slowly. Unfortunately you can't explicitly set ship facing, making planning ahead a challenge, and during combat capital ships can veer off-target if their pathfinding AI decides that it needs to steer around an obstacle. With capital ship battles often decided by the direction in which each ship is pointing, this easily becomes a pain point.Otherwise ships can either fire in all directions or turn quickly enough that their current facing doesn't matter. There is no apparent bonus for hitting ships from the rear unless you are specifically trying to disable their engines, a niche activity given how slowly ships large enough to have targetable sub-systems move. There really is vanishingly little else to discuss at a high level.The automatic difficulty scaling of the campaign, in which the number of enemy opponents changes depending on how many ships you carry over from the previous mission, was ahead of its time. Unfortunately the AI will simply clump all its ships of the same type together and order them about as one unit, which actually makes the campaign easier as it progresses due to the slower response times required by larger battles. You'll coast through the campaigns until their final missions, which both spike difficulty up to the same obscene level. They are disasters and I would suggest just watching the closing cut-scenes online instead of bothering with either.I paid £9 for the game when it was on sale and am not unhappy with that. But I cannot recommend it for £27 nearly two years after release.(I didn't play online, but I hear that it's dead.)

I have been told online that I literally have to start over again from the previous mission.And the winner is - on the tutorial there is a 'press ok to continue' mechanic.... but the voice just keeps on going whether you press ok or not... It's only an annoyance but to me it's emblematic of the trashy quality of this port.Do not buy this for HW1, you will be disappointed by how buggy and glitchy it is.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												First! Will update this after I'm done drooling all over it.All right, I've done a quick match and quickly destroyed my AI opponent. I'm a HW1/HW2 vet and I first played Homeworld in '99, so here's my input:Pros:-I like how the controls feel like Homeworld 2, most of the shortcuts are the same even though the UI is redesigned. The HW1 interface was terribad in comparison, I'm glad the devs went with the new version.-So many pretty things, and yet it runs quite smooth on my laptop. Kudos for good optimization.Cons:-Scuttling is too easy to do, there should be somekind of confirmation in case I press the wrong button.-I found the UI too small to be honest, the difference between size 1 and 2 is too big (size 1 being miniature and size 2 being gigantic for my 1600x900 resolution), it'd be quite essential to be able to tell what's going on. The selected unit icons are essential in managing strikecraft. -The asteroids are too hard to see on the tactical screen, they are an important strategy element and I'd like to see them better. -At first I was disappointed that I couldn't launch the multiplayer and the two campaigns from the same ingame menu, but then I realized it's probably that way to save loading times (perhaps, maybe the devs were just lazy). -The multiplayer obviously needs some improvement, but it's in beta which gives me hope the devs will actively work on it. Perhaps balance things as time goes on? That'd be sweet.-The chat. Come on, the messed up keyboard layout is a HW2 bug, at least try to fix it.All in all, worth every penny so far.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Please note: I am not some nub scrub who doesn't understand homeworld. I was playing and writing games in the 70s before most of those reading this reveiw were born, before some of their parents were born O.o. I have played all the homeworld games and I started on the RTS around 1992 with Dune 2. I can still beat 12 year olds a dark souls 2 pvp so please, no ageist BS. Can't really recommend this bundle at the moment as it doesn't seem finished. The problem is the "remastered" Homeworld 1. Some random observations:Problems arise first in the tutorial where it keeps asking you to press "ok" to continue, and then continues whether you do or don't. Key assignments don't seem to work: I reassigned keys for panning up/down and suddenly i couldn't pan backwards and forwards or up and down with keys and my mouse wouldn't go back/forwards, instead it went up/down.  It seems plagued by flickering textures and lighting issues.There seem to be some problems with selecting units and control at times. At the end of a mission I was harvesting but the harvesters all ignored the harvest controller  nearby and went to the mothership. Also has problems with streaming via steam and also if you have MSI afterburner running.  Not that either is hard to avoid but they're also not that hard to program around (given the number of games out there which manage it).HW1 also has the homeworld 2 control and manufacturing systems but they don't seem to work consistently, in the tutorial you manufacture a whole wing of ships, not so in the missions where they pop out one at a time.Homeworld 2 is much better and haven't really encountered any problems with it but what you're paying for here is a collection. If half a working package minus multiplayer is enough for you then sure, buy it, but if not, wait. Not sure how this is getting 9/10s other than the usual game industry BS. Hopefully things will improve with time but experience teaches not to expect it.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												In the current state i can only recommend against buying this game.It very much feels like a (very pretty) beta that has enough technical issues to feel nearly as bad as the original.If Gearbox manages to actually improve things i will amend this.As it is, have a small list of problems discovered in the first 10 minutes of gameplay: The mouse has lag (even at 160 fps), there's some form of mouse acceleration at work (most noticable when scrolling to zoom in, but not when zooming out) and there's not even a sensitivity slider, with the default being very low. (Fairly important for things like rotating the camera.) Panning to the left is nearly impossible on a multi-monitor setup since the mouse is not captured in the game window. The hud on a 1920x1200 screen is small, but can be increased in size by factors 2, 3, 4. However even a factor of 2 is already too much, since every element is literally doubled in height and width.Multiplayer is currently in beta, and makes the same mistake that killed multiplayer for the original: It forces usage of a centralized third-party service which may die at any time. There is an option for LAN multiplayer, but that is unlikely to work well on the internet.As a postscript: Since the original version is included, it's recommended to simply play that. It also has a tiny UI, but a very sharply-designed one, and the screen is locked to 4:3, but otherwise it does not exhibit the beta-like issues of the remaster.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												UPDATE: Tried to run Homeworld 2 Remastered, game won't launch. Score updated appropriately.I've only had a brief time with the game but here's my initial experiences/opinions from playing the Homeworld 1 Remastered campaign:First the bad;1) Controls not rebindable. Tried with several keys on one command, and half a dozen different commands after and even clearing the keys from commands before attempting to add new ones results in an error message blocking you from rebinding ("the key is already in use as "command"").2) First mission glitched, skipped initial objective rendering the mission impossible to finish. Restarted mission to try again, all going well until told to capture drone with salvage ship, whereupon my fighters (set on aggressive mode, as per the previous objective instructions) sped half way across the map to kill it before my salvage ship got there, resulting in another failed mission. Third time's the charm and I finally finish it.3) Second mission goes well. Apart from a brief issue getting my ship to behave, which I suggest was my fault, the mission went smoothly, enemy ships were fought,♥♥♥♥♥♥exploded, all went well.4) Third mission again bugged. Told to kill one assault frigate and capture the other with salvage ship. Salvage ship will approach the frigate but refuses to interact with it, no matter how much damage I deal first. Thought I might be missing a ship but the research menu shows no further research to be made.5) Sound for weapons firing keeps cutting out. Looks like a sound channels issue but even after bumping it from the default (apparently 0, but obviously not otherwise there'd have been no sound) to 100 the problem persists.6) Lighting issues, you can rotate the camera to blatantly see the sun in the background but the side of an object facing you is still brightly lit up, while it has shadows around the edge (as though your camera is a brighter light source than the sun. It's a little nitpick but it bugs the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me nontheless.Now the good;1) The remastered textures are pretty, even on moderate settings and zoomed in far the game looks amazing.2) The cutscenes are great too.3) Having Homeworld 2's UI in the Homeworld 1 campaign is a blessing, probably the best design decision they've made overall. I really can't stress how great this is.4) The new music is spectacular, that opening cutscene where the mothership undocks has some great music.5) Alt-F4 works.Finally, the ugly;1) There's no game speed option. I can't remember if the classic Homeworld had it or not but not having one in a more modern game is just plain silly. Resource collectors can take upwards of 2-3 minutes to grab a handful of resources (often only enough for one or two ships or a single research project) and can't be sped up. Any game that puts me in a situation where I'm actively flicking through a magazine while playing is not winning brownie points.2) There are 4 UI scale options (not on the options screen, but rather the pause (F10) screen. It's a nice feature to have but at size 2 the UI's group panel (where you assign tactics and formations) is too small to read and at size 3 it takes up about two-thirds of the screen space and leaves you a tiny rectangle in the middle to play with. This could be solved quite easily with more granular options like a slider instead of just 4 settings.All that said; it's Homeworld - they're great games and nothing will change that.Overall: I can't recommend it. It feels like an old game dragged kicking and screaming into the modern era, which is equal parts good and bad (mostly good, thankfully) but the bugs and glitches had me reaching for Alt-F4 after only two and a bit missions of the campaign. Typically the start of a game is more polished than the end (simply because it has more time with the playtesters) and if the quality of the first three missions is anything to go by the rest of the game must be an absolute trainwreck.Add in the fact that the multiplayer is still in beta, which is a broad definition these days anyway, while the game is billed as a full release and you've got something that stinks of being rushed out the door to take advantage of a rapidly depopulated release window.Sorry Gearbox but you've blown it pretty hard at release.Score: 1 "It's dead Jim" out of 10.

number of helpful: 6 of 54 people (11%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												So once again I was led to think a old game is great. Never played before. I love space RTS. Sins was by far the best ever made. Because of all the hype and people claiming HW is the best I just had to give it a try and was happy to see they were remastering it and selling here on Steam. Big mistake to listen to people once again. For all of you out there that are looking for a great RTS/4x space game, and expect the UI to be good then do not buy this game. Here's why. If you come from playing Sins of a Solar Empire you will know that the user interface is simply the best and easiest. Why any game out there does not do this to this day is beyoned me. SInce the Devs claimed they "remastered" this game I expected that they would truly put it up to par with what a great game should be today. They did not. I suspect the UI was no diferent when the game was first made to now with the remastered. So really all that was done was graphics update. Thats it. Made the game look pretty. Well this was great but why the hell could you not update the UI? I'm sorry but I just think once again I wasted my money on another space game that could have been great with very simple UI updates. How hard is it to do a "stratigic Zoom" such as in Sin's???? Why is this so hard to accomplish by game Devs? Why do I have to go though steps and press multiple keys in order to zoom in on a ship and pan around to get a good view of a battle? Why? Hopfully there will be a new game soon that can accomplish this very apparently hard task. For old players returning I'm asumimg you dont care and love the game just the way it is. Fine. If thats whom the Devs want to sell to okay then. To anyone new looking to buy the game and expect it to be easy and intuitive UI dont expect much. Pros: Im sorry but its not fun to have to deal with the UI and therefore has ruined the game completely. No pros. Poorly remade. Devs wanted a quick buck by remaking the graphics and changed nothing else to make it a fun and easy to use game.Cons: 1. Crashes on a pretty regular bases. Did not harp on this to much because I'm asuming is a simple bug that will get adressed soon? 2. Horrible old UI that is just completly a turn off. Waste of a potentially good game. 3. No multiplayer. Or at least did not see how to do it.  4. Horrible tutorial. Very buggy. Very basic. Crashes.5. In a good game when you hover the mouse over a subject in the game you get a good description in a paragraph or so describing what it is. This was very poorly done if at all on some items and areas of the game. Basically figure it all out your self guys. Verry didsapointed. Please someone make a good space game like Sin's again with a seamless and sratigic zoom. There is no reason I should have to push multiple keys to acomplish camerea and UI features. Should all be simple and done with the mouse.

												These games took quite a bit of messing around and looking up issues on the forums in order to get to work on my system.  Now that they are working, the remastered versions look amazing, however there are still quite a few bugs to workout.  Such as ship formations, tactics, mouse speeds, and general balancing.  Further some of the missions appear to be bugged as well..The classic versions of these games are unaltered, and are almost more playable than the remastered versions because of the ability to use formations and tactics.  However, the options to change the game resolutions are lacking... no widescreen options at all.  I guess you could go into the registry and edit this to force it to work at a higher resolution, but again, it takes a lot of work to get the program to run the way you want it.  Although they are unaltered, I do wish they built in a few more graphics options.  Further Homeworld Classic crashes on mission 4 in the campaign.  I have not found a workaround for this yet...I played the remastered versions for a few hours and although they are stunning to look at, the mechanics are very lacking still...... So for now, i'm playing the classic versions until the remastered versions are fixed.

content:
Posted: March 8
												When this game first came out I was very happy with the visuals and all of the fluff, everything was well done and felt great.I'll precurse with this: If you have never played Homeworld 1 singleplayer, GET THIS GAME, I don't care if you play the original or the Remaster, get this ♥♥♥♥ing game and PLAY THE SINGLEPLAYER, don't spoil any of the story, go in as blind as possible, DO IT.Other than, the glaring flaws, the butchering of formations, the removal of projectiles, the implementation of Homeworld 1 mechanics had failed when attempting to use an upgraded version of Homeworld 2, a game that stripped many essential features out in exchange for making a smoother multiplayer experience.Back on release I wouldn't have reccomended the game, but times change, and as the ancient guidestone and legends fortold, we WOULD return to Higarra.With the updates since, projectiles have been reintroduced, the terrible Homeworld 2 mechanics have been stripped from HW1 and there's even been steps made to make Homeworld 2 backwards compatible with some central mechanics from the first game, such as formations and real simulated projectiles. Homeworld 1 Remastered operates roughly as how I remember it now, the old experience has been recreated dutifully and the mechanics being changed to match turns this from an old reference to a true recreation of the experience.Homeworld 1 Remastered is fantastic and essentially can now replace the original for me (however it still will hold a place in my heart)Homeworld: Cataclysm Remastered would be a dream come true but I'm not sure that's going to happen.And Homeworld 2 Remastered is, well, it's alright. Boring story, less interesting gameplay and story overall, less connection to your fleet, but hey! The multiplayer is pretty cool.Entirely reccomend if you haven't played homeworld before.

content:

												I have been following the journey of the HomeWorld series for a long time now. From when me and my brother played it together originally all those years ago to the confusing bio ships of cataclysm that everyone tried to forget and on to the amazing HW2 (oh and lets not forget the Complex mod!! amazing work).So when i heard HW was getting a dust off and a new coat of paint i honestly couldnt wait. It doesnt disappoint, the game is gorgeous and the whole presentation of the package is ...acceptable. I say "acceptable" because the way it is packaged feels like it has lost some of its ..strength of character. The game is still there, the music (which is amazing!!) and the gameplay are as remembered but now it has a feeling of being squashed together and in someway lost some of its uniqueness. I focus mainly here on the multiplayer game, there are some strongly unbalanced aspects of joining all four races together such as the core stats of some of the original ships, this in my humble opinion should be looked at a lor more closely to give a better cohesion between races and better gameplay for the buyer.Saying that, i enjoyed the new "raiders" content and i appreciate all the work the devs are doing and hopefully will be doing to further stream line the experience.In short, buy it. the game is iconic and a still havnt found another like it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												What new can I possibly write about Homeworld and its sequel? Unique in time of their original releases, both games still hold up well, after all those years, and prove that design is everything when it comes to creating memorable gaming experiences. Despite somewhat dated appearance both are still very much playable, though I personally have much trouble getting both old versions to run properly on my modern hardware. Thus comes the Remastered Collection, allowing me to again experience both games.You see, I never played Homeworld games specifically for their mechanics, but rather – for one-of-a-kind atmosphere, fantastically designed universe and somewhat mystical approach to space travel. For me, those two games were just wonderful, interactive stories, and strategic gameplay was only a package in which they were delivered. This is probably what makes me oblivious to all the mechanical alterations, and maybe even flaws, that Gearbox has introduced in this remaster. As for the stories themselves I will not say a word – they are to be experienced personally.Mechanically, Homeworld is an RTS in 3D space, to put it bluntly. You collect resources, build units, attack enemies and win missions either by destruction, timer, capture or any combination of those. Sounds pretty standard, right? Well, it is, sort of. Third dimension adds a new element to unit positioning, and in this game it really matters which units attack which targets, in which order and how they are set up in space. You need to apply formations effective in each situation, change unit tactics and generally move around the battlefield a lot more than in a standard RTS. More often than not games also ask for quite a degree of multitasking – luckily in singleplayer active pause comes in handy, allowing to place orders and think out the situation before acting.As I mentioned, not everything works as it should in Homeworld Remastered. Especially in the first campaign it is evident that a lot of things broke when transplanted onto the new game engine. Omission of refuelling mechanic drastically changes the way strike craft operates and renders some ships almost useless. It is worth mentioning though that in the instance of Kadeshi fighters the fuel did seem to run out for them, so it is rather inconsistent. Conversely, in Homeworld 2 Remastered formations seem largely broken. There are more things behaving differently from original, so purists and hardcore game fans will be put off, but I – for reasons I mentioned above – enjoyed both campaigns to the fullest. Sure, sometimes I had to put more clickwork to make things fly around as intended, however none of the issues would break the game for me.I have not tested the multiplayer component yet, though I am not much of an online gamer so I might never do that actually. Keep in mind that my review is from single player standpoint only. Also I’d like to point out that the lack of Cataclysm in the remaster is a bit disappointing, but maybe, just maybe, some day they will be able to release that too.From a visual standpoint, the game is the definition of what a “remaster” should be. Every model in the game has been reworked from ground up and even the smallest fighters are now more detailed than largest capital ships in the original Homeworld. Great texturework is accompanied by a set of subtle effects like volumetric lighting, multiple-source dynamic shadows and lighting, depth of field and of course high resolution support. Animatics between missions have been re-drawn in high definition and compressed with quality in mind. Homeworld Remastered Collection is simply gorgeous. Stunning visuals are accompanied by great voiceover and absolutely stunning soundtrack, which is as far as I’m concerned absolutely unique in games world, combining ethnic and symphonic themes into one. The game simply feels majestic at times. Audio has been, of course, cleaned up since the original.Overall, there is really no reason one should not get Homeworld Remastered Collection. It is a great re-release of two great real time strategy games, providing many hours of gameplay even in single player mode, though I'll state this again - for me most important here are the epic story and atmosphere. There is already extensive mod support too, meaning that fans of altering the game will be able to find something for themselves, and purists should be able to ‘fix’ the game soon enough. In terms of presentation it’s flawless. If it was flawless mechanically, we’d have an absolute remaster benchmark on our hands. As it is, it’s just great.

												I am a huge fan of the homeworld series having spent numorous and incalculable hours in the trilogy. However, currently HW1 has been dumbed down extremely badly.HW11) The repair vessels no longer autorepair and their range has been crippled terribly!2) The salvage corvettes AI has been damaged too, and the result is you have to micromanage those ships.3) Ship AI in general is a bit sluggish4) HW1 remastered has a bug where you can't get into our get out of the command overview screen.5) The last is a bit picky as you can no longer edit your fleet colors or choose which race to play in the beginning.I love this game but until a patch comes out I can't give it a positive review and since I have to make a choice it goes negative as this near perfect game needs some polish.

Thus comes the Remastered Collection, allowing me to again experience both games.You see, I never played Homeworld games specifically for their mechanics, but rather – for one-of-a-kind atmosphere, fantastically designed universe and somewhat mystical approach to space travel. For me, those two games were just wonderful, interactive stories, and strategic gameplay was only a package in which they were delivered. This is probably what makes me oblivious to all the mechanical alterations, and maybe even flaws, that Gearbox has introduced in this remaster. As for the stories themselves I will not say a word – they are to be experienced personally.Mechanically, Homeworld is an RTS in 3D space, to put it bluntly. You collect resources, build units, attack enemies and win missions either by destruction, timer, capture or any combination of those. Sounds pretty standard, right? Well, it is, sort of. Third dimension adds a new element to unit positioning, and in this game it really matters which units attack which targets, in which order and how they are set up in space. You need to apply formations effective in each situation, change unit tactics and generally move around the battlefield a lot more than in a standard RTS. More often than not games also ask for quite a degree of multitasking – luckily in singleplayer active pause comes in handy, allowing to place orders and think out the situation before acting.As I mentioned, not everything works as it should in Homeworld Remastered. Especially in the first campaign it is evident that a lot of things broke when transplanted onto the new game engine. Omission of refuelling mechanic drastically changes the way strike craft operates and renders some ships almost useless. It is worth mentioning though that in the instance of Kadeshi fighters the fuel did seem to run out for them, so it is rather inconsistent. Conversely, in Homeworld 2 Remastered formations seem largely broken. There are more things behaving differently from original, so purists and hardcore game fans will be put off, but I – for reasons I mentioned above – enjoyed both campaigns to the fullest. Sure, sometimes I had to put more clickwork to make things fly around as intended, however none of the issues would break the game for me.I have not tested the multiplayer component yet, though I am not much of an online gamer so I might never do that actually. Keep in mind that my review is from single player standpoint only. Also I’d like to point out that the lack of Cataclysm in the remaster is a bit disappointing, but maybe, just maybe, some day they will be able to release that too.From a visual standpoint, the game is the definition of what a “remaster” should be. Every model in the game has been reworked from ground up and even the smallest fighters are now more detailed than largest capital ships in the original Homeworld. Great texturework is accompanied by a set of subtle effects like volumetric lighting, multiple-source dynamic shadows and lighting, depth of field and of course high resolution support. Animatics between missions have been re-drawn in high definition and compressed with quality in mind. Homeworld Remastered Collection is simply gorgeous. Stunning visuals are accompanied by great voiceover and absolutely stunning soundtrack, which is as far as I’m concerned absolutely unique in games world, combining ethnic and symphonic themes into one. The game simply feels majestic at times. Audio has been, of course, cleaned up since the original.Overall, there is really no reason one should not get Homeworld Remastered Collection. It is a great re-release of two great real time strategy games, providing many hours of gameplay even in single player mode, though I'll state this again - for me most important here are the epic story and atmosphere. There is already extensive mod support too, meaning that fans of altering the game will be able to find something for themselves, and purists should be able to ‘fix’ the game soon enough. In terms of presentation it’s flawless. If it was flawless mechanically, we’d have an absolute remaster benchmark on our hands. As it is, it’s just great.

												The Homeworld franchise was one of the few series of games I completed and, more astonishingly, kept going back to and finishing again and again. Few games hit the sweet spot between atmosphere, empathy and sheer joy. These were among them.So how does the remastering match up? In all honesty, it has a few problems. They are minor, very minor and to be fair to the developers - anything less than perfection was going to be unjustly highlighted. None of the problems are show stoppers; sure - you have to micromanage your fleets a little more, sure - sometimes they get a little carried away and don't do precisely what you tell them to do, but hey! This is Homeworld! Remastered!I can forgive a lot more than the minor infractions this game has because the developers took the time and effort to raise a classic from our past and give it new life. Posted: August 4, 2015
												I have been looking for a game like this since I was about 10 years old. Now I can say that i have found it:A space RTS with huge scale.(I'm currently playing Homeworld Remastered)Campaign: You play as the Kushdan trying to escape the vice of the Taiidan Empire,each mission tells the story of the Kushdan mothership and other smaller ships, and their journey to the edge of the galaxy, and away from the danger of the Taiidan. Some mission offer variety, such as shooting asteroids to shield the mothership from damage or fighting off swarms of small pod ships that hail from a alien race in a nebula. I'm stuck on a difficult mission right now but hope to finish soon.Player v Computer:Basically the same thing as Skirmish in other RTS games. Choose a race. Choose an enemy. Destroy the enemy capital ships and Mothership. Collect resources. Have fun.Extra missions: Unlocked as you progress through the Campaign. One mission included has you destroy an enemy convoy.Soundtrack: Made by (god knows who, I don't care really), and reminds me of EVE Online and FTL music put together. Music changes depending on the combat situation of either the mission or your units in the battle zone.I give Homeworld Remastered a 9/10 (and I'm sorry I didn't review Homeworld Two Homeworld one has swallowed enough of my time :) )

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												The overall "Homeworld" experience is really fantastic. The games got all the mechanical and artistic elements right, from the way the gameplay and GUI interact, to the music, to the story, to the artwork - the series is legenday for good reason.There is a pretty big "YMMV" point when you play it again, though.See, when you play the games the first time, you're awed by the experience as a whole. The artistry of it all just kind of overwhelms you. However, when you come back to the games (especially "Homeworld 2") after a good long while, a bit of disappointment does creep in. You're no longer gaping in amazement at the setting, and so the macro-structure of the gameplay becomes more noticeable.The "Homeworld" series - at least to me - takes the unfortunate route of melding a single-solution puzzle with the RTS genre. You can't really find your own groove. Instead, you end up having to figure out "the one magic trick" that gets you through the mission. To me, that's an unwelcome subversion of the strategy element. The player's choices seem frustratingly constrained at times, whether it's from a lack of available resources or from the scenario requiring a very specific fleet structure.The achievement that is the "Homeworld" saga is, in the end, dimmed only slightly by this problem. I still see the series as THE Gold Standard for this kind of game. This remaster is 100% worth picking up; I just think it's also worth mentioning that certain choices regarding the gameplay might not be everybody's cup of tea.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												I am a new fan to the Homeworld series, having still been playing with Legos when the original games came out. As such, my review is unbiased. That is not to say that I haven't played the originals at all, as they are both available along with the Remastered versions free of charge.Pros: The game's graphics have been modernized in the best ways possible. That is not to say it'll kill your pc, as I run this game fairly well on my stock laptop at max graphics. The interactions between objects looks great (resource collectors docking with flagships, units being launched from carriers, etc.)The game has a great modding community that works hard to bring a new experience once you've decided you want to see more in the same game.Cons: Many old fans will tell you this, and I am inclined to agree: Formations are broken. In the classics, units in formations would hold formation at all times, but the Remastered formations simply affect what your forces do before they meet an enemy unit. They break formation and act as if they never had one in the first place until they get a new move order. However, Gearbox is working on fixing that issue, and in the Remasters there are more formations, allowing for a more diverse screenshot at the moment. Hopefully we can see that fixed soon.The multiplayer is still a beta, as it mixes both game's factions into the same game and thus has balance issues. Again, this is being worked on.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												My introduction to the whole Homeworld saga began with Cataclysm, a game I tried to play when I was thereabouts 6, and so frustrated with its difficulty, gave it up for years. Years later, I picked it up and learned it thoroughly, and enjoyed it, and marvelled at the rich history of this game I thought had been a standalone.Delightfully surprised, years later, to find and buyHomeworld 2, my re-introduction to the series has been completely backwards, in unravelling. This remastered collection is a fantastic culimination of the first two Homeworld games, graphically superb in nearly every way, the first of which I've only just finished playing after writing this review.The Remastered collection is as I expected, graphically improved. Many hardcore fans, however, point out changes to the game's original mechanics (the original titles, however, are also included in this should you wish to play those). What you get is essentially four games, two that look better than the others, both with the occasional hiccup I can forgive because it's such a solid experience, no other RTS had (or has, really) a 3-dimensional map, both up and down in space; not to mention the wonderful take on the whole Moses in the desert, trying to find Zion.If you've still got your old Homeworld disks, and are thinking about buying this game, then all you'd probably get out of it is a slicker ride; those newcomers who have yet to experience the game and want it al dressed up, just want to see what all the fuss is about, or want a trip down memory lane in style, then this is the game for you.10/10 would find Israel again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												As someone who has indeed played the original (albeit never beat it since I was still quite young, stuck on the supernova research station level hahaha), I have to say that this collection is a MUST have and a MUST play for any and all fans of RTS games and great stories, not to mention it having an amazing middle-eastern influenced soundtrack, and really cool space ship designs. Yes, the HW1 remaster does have issues with it's strike craft AI being really stupid at times because of issues with remaking HW1 with the HW2 engine but that won't hurt your overall enjoyment of the game; it was still quite the enjoyable experience (the HW2 remaster works just fine). And in addition, if you're a veteran and are stubborn to accept crappy HW1 strike craft AI, they've even bundled the original HW1 and 2 with this deal! It CAN be quite challenging to newcomers but you can easily learn from initial mistakes and adapt.A few tips for new players:general:-remember that resources and your fleet are persistent, meaning they carry through each level in both HW 1 and 2's campaigns; try not to loose too many ships or waste too many resources or else you could be setting yourself up to being forced to restart from the very beginning-in the remaster, any resources you have not yet harvested in a level by the end of the level will automatically be added to your resource unit count once you hyperspace to the next level, so no need waiting for your collectors, if you've developed that habit as veteran HW player.HW1:-USE SALVAGE CORVETTES; I cannot stress how important capturing ships is. Capture as often as possible and in this priority order: Heavy cruisers>destroyers(any type)>ion cannon frigates>assault or support frigates. Heck, capture a few turanic raider corvettes in the earlier levels. Early in the game when you're really strapped for resources, capturing is the best way to acquire a powerful fleet.-stop using fighters all together other than bombers when you're at late/end game in the campaign: as I have stated, fighter AI in HW 1 remastered is quite dumb, and I've literally had an entire wing of 30-40 defenders wiped out in seconds. Bombers are still somewhat useful for adding additional damage when attacking capital ships however. For all strike craft vs. strike craft engagements in late/endgame, you should be using purely multigun corvettes. -take advantage of the time the game gives you when you've cleared the level and rebuild any lost ships before you hyperspace to the next level. Many levels in this game pits you against massive forces right from the start of the level and you will want to be very prepared for anything. You will not have this luxury for the most part in HW2, btw. HW2:-Flak frigates, marine frigates, defense field frigates, proximity sensor probes, and sensor distortion probes are completely useless; do NOT invest/use them. Capturing in HW2 is pretty much useless, since anything and everything can and will shoot down marine frigates in time while they are boarding an enemy ship, but unfortunately some levels require you to use one to fulfill mission objectives, in which you should build them for that and then retire immediately afterwards and use that space for an ion or torpedo frigate instead. Same goes for that defense field frigate which has a virtually useless shield ability that lasts like 5 seconds, but you will need 2 of them for this one mission objective in this one level, so likewise, retire them when you're done with them.-Use carriers more: HW2 does not have support frigates nor effective salvaging ships, so you'll have to approach this game a bit differently in general. I highly recommend sending out a carrier behind your main fleet to act as a repair station/support frigate to repair strike craft wings and to also keep building/supplying fresh new ships to your main fighting groups because unlike in HW1, you will be building most of your fleet on  your own instead of capturing. -delay mission objectives whenever possible to rebuild your fleet: having your fleet at full maxed out fighting power is important more than ever now with how much salvaging sucks in this compared to HW1. You do gain alot more resources alot more quickly so you should almost always have the full 14 fighter squadrons, 12 corvette squadrons, 21 frigates, and later on 5 destroyers and 2 battlecruisers cap, or at least keep it that way whenever possible (and before the final mission at least, have the cap of 4 carriers, trust me, you'll be thanking me in the final mission).-strike craft are actually VERY good this time, so DO NOT hesistate to use interceptors and bombers. Use the pulsar gunships in conjunction with bombers to attack frigates and capital ships but also against corvettes whenever needed.-always pick torpedo frigates over flak frigates, like, ALWAYS; flak frigates suck. anyways, tl;dr,  I LOVE homeworld and I wholeheartedly recommend this game. I really hope gearbox decides to do HW cataclysm in the future even if they lost source code and would have to rebuild the assets from scratch; the beast and kiith somtaw were badass.

												A fairly great remaster of an RTS classic. Some minor issues early on but hopefully they've been fixed by now.Homeworld in my book is a legendary game, and it's hard for a remaster to fault it in any way. It's one of the few early games to offer a 3rd dimension for an RTS. Storyline still holds its weight to this day as well.The remaster brings both games into an updated version of the HW2 engine. Complete with fully remastered music, sound effects and voiceovers. But they left out the ending credits featuring Yes? That was a letdown.If you're a fan of Homeworld, you won't be disappointed. If you've never played Homeworld then I'd suggest you pick this up.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												I have been looking for a game like this since I was about 10 years old. Now I can say that i have found it:A space RTS with huge scale.(I'm currently playing Homeworld Remastered)Campaign: You play as the Kushdan trying to escape the vice of the Taiidan Empire,each mission tells the story of the Kushdan mothership and other smaller ships, and their journey to the edge of the galaxy, and away from the danger of the Taiidan. Some mission offer variety, such as shooting asteroids to shield the mothership from damage or fighting off swarms of small pod ships that hail from a alien race in a nebula. I'm stuck on a difficult mission right now but hope to finish soon.Player v Computer:Basically the same thing as Skirmish in other RTS games. Choose a race. Choose an enemy. Destroy the enemy capital ships and Mothership. Collect resources. Have fun.Extra missions: Unlocked as you progress through the Campaign. One mission included has you destroy an enemy convoy.Soundtrack: Made by (god knows who, I don't care really), and reminds me of EVE Online and FTL music put together. Music changes depending on the combat situation of either the mission or your units in the battle zone.I give Homeworld Remastered a 9/10 (and I'm sorry I didn't review Homeworld Two Homeworld one has swallowed enough of my time :) )

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												I decided to play through both H1 and 2 before writing a review, just to make sure I had an accurate idea of what has been changed. I'm not going to say much about the original Homeworld releases - I'm sure there's years of reviews already, suffice to say you will already know if you like this kind of thing.Without a doubt, this Remaster is one of the best examples of it's kind, applied to one of the best RTS games ever made. Graphically, it's sublime - the upgraded textures and effects make this look like some kind of blockbuster sci-fi movie, only you're playing it rather than watching it. The missions themselves have been tweaked slightly to make them a little less ridiculous - Gearbox are already posting fixes and further tweaks to the aspects of the missions that were less hard and more simply unfair (Radiation patches in missions being much easier to see, for example). The missions are still something of a challenge (including the fun Thaddis Sabah mission where the opposing Vaygr forces seemingly don't have a population cap) and both titles are still games of the early noughties.... i.e. you are expected to use your grey matter as much as your reflexes - but the core gameplay was so ahead of it's time that when attached to the new visuals, it looks like a brand new AAA title.I believe they've updated the voice actors in H2 to use the same ones they used in H1, and the new UI is common to both versions. The resulting effect is that the games feel like different chapters of the same story rather than seperate games, and I'll be honest, the package works better for it. There are a few negatives. The 'Collection' doesn't include the cleaned up, ultra-impressive remastered soundtracks, instead presented as DLCs. Personally I think they should have been given the 'all-inclusive' nature of the release, but meh. A minor nitpick that you can rectify in the next Steam sale.Formations are a bit broken. Ships still assume them when ordered but break when they do something else, some of the time. I do have to admit that this was an aspect of the original games that I never really bothered with that much, and given Gearbox's track record for supporting this game it wouldn't surprise me if it's patched by the time you read this review. The games's (particularly H2) annoying habit of dragging your attention away mid-battle for a cutscene is still here, and it doesn't include Homeworld Cataclysm, on account of it's source code apparently being lost. It apparently crashes in MP often, but I don't do much MP so can't say that with any certainty.It's not quite perfect.... but if you're into space games, RTS, or simply truly amazing gameplay, you will find this to be awfully near to it. The only people I wouldn't recommend this collection to are people who dislike sci-fi or fans of mediocrity.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												This is one of the most masterful games I've ever played in my entire life.  The campaigns are astonishing, and truly draw you into the world.  They make you want to protect your people, and lead your fleet in the best way possible.  The graphics, the gameplay, and especially the realism (minus sound in space, but I don't care about that) of the battles are unparalelled in other games.  It may be that it is simple by comparison with almost every space game ever (what with only having one resource that you can gather in finite amounts) and that is one part that detracts from this game's replayability.  The campaigns are so astonishing that it's worth the asking price, but I give this warning:If you are thinking about buying this game and you're not really interested in a good story, then this is not for you.  Yes, if you're interested in just haphazardly throwing fleets against one another then it will do so in a beautiful, fun, and incredibly tactically pleasing fashion, but we all know that that gets old eventually.  This game will rely on mods for continued replayability in skirmish mode, but if even a small part of you likes stories and getting emotionally invested in a game, or just want to play a space game where tactical genius actually matters, then this game is for you.

												Not a remastered edition but a rehashed one. If you've played the original, don't try this - keep your money, memories and old copy intact. If you haven't played Homeworld and can't handle anything but the latest graphics then this is the one for you.Alot of the other reviews sum it up perfectly, some particular points that require ephasis though:-Formations are broken and do not work.-Completely different unit balances compared to the original (especially frigates. They are now just lumps of RUs that specialise in sploding real good).-HW1 remastered hit system is all based on a system of probabilities of hitting a target (like HW2) instead of an actual hit is a hit. As HW1 was designed on an actual hit system, this mucks up the gameplay. Adding to this is HW2's specialisation system coming into play (eg assault frigates are good vs fighters, so if you tell them to attack corvettes, a slower and larger target, all their shots will still miss as they are not a unit "good vs corvettes"). It is basically a port of HW1 into HW2 therefore if you want to play using the remastered graphics but the orginal gameplay style (of HW1), you can't (defeats the purpose of buying remastered)-Units behave differently than the original Homeworlds (eg corvettes circling an enemy now only use half their guns) - above explains part of this too.-Complete lie when they say you will get the original games - they've fondled all LAN and multiplayer options out of them which is so substantial a change that they can't be considered as original verisons. Therefore you can't play multiplayer with the classics - a key feature which THE CLASSICS HAD (and it wasn't a multiplayer beta strap on like this "remastered" edition has. That's right people, when the original Homeworld came out, multiplayer in the Homeworld universe was not in beta - it was already COMPLETE)Given this is a "mastering" of a classic, of which all they had to do was improve the graphics, its a very poor show and blatant cash grab leveraging on Homeworld's reputation established so long ago.Will have to consider greatly before buying anything from Gearbox Software

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Homeworld is a legendary PC game and I'd love to be able to recommend this Remastered Collection.  At first glance it's everything it was promised to be: a rebuilt version of Homeworld 1 & 2 (no HW:Cataclysm unfortunately) using an updated engine to make the games much prettier, fix many compatibility issues, and address various long-standing bugs.The reason I can't give that recommendation is that the new engine shared by Homeworld 1&2 in this remake is based on Homeworld 2's engine, and it's a fundamentally different game from Homeworld 1.  Many of the issues this causes are cosmetic but others make the game borderline unplayable.  The two most egregious flaws introduced are to do with the "formation" and "tactics" systems.Formations are theoretically still in the game but ships now break formation for almost any reason.  This frequently reduces the core of the game's combat system to little more than "have more ships at the fight than your opponent".  You used to be able to do things like attack from multiple directions while keeping your ships in effective groupings, put your ships into a wall formation to bring more firepower to bear at once, put them in a sphere formation to guard a weaker ship, and so on - none of this works anymore.  You can still take advantage of weaker armor in different areas of your enemy's ships, but it's a disorganized mess.The tactics system, which previously made the difference between your ships focusing on maneuverability or firepower, has been stripped out altogether.  This used to be a very valuable game mechanic, allowing you to press your advantage in one-sided battle to quickly end it before enemy reinforcements arrived, or use maneuverable mode to escape unfavorable situations.  The tactics system is now the same as Homeworld 2's, and basically every other RTS: aggressive (attack on sight), defensive (attack if attacked), and passive (ignore enemies).  This might not sound like a big deal if you've never played Homeworld before, but it was one of the most unique aspects of the game, and it functioned extremely well in combination with smart formation choices.Lesser but still important issues are to do with changes to the game's interface and how various ships function.The game's main user interface has been replaced with one inspired by Homeworld 2, which had much simpler "rock-paper-scissors" ship balancing and all that really mattered was "this ship is good against this ship".  Homeworld 1 was more complex than this though and its UI gave you appropriately more complex information, including things like fire arc coverage - a major differentiating factor between different ship types.  This is vital information, removed in service of making the game more accessible, but it has the opposite effect: new players won't know what the real advantages between different ships really are, and this is a game that severely punishes choosing the wrong fleet composition.As for the functional issues with various ships, unfortunately there's not much I can say.  I threw up my hands in disgust long before I had the opportunity to experience more than the first five or so missions and a bit of the multiplayer, so there's a lot of stuff I only know about based on what I've heard others say, like how repair ships are apparently broken in some way.  One thing I know about is that the concept of fuel has been removed, and this has huge gameplay implications.  I don't like this change, it's like if Valve added regenerating health and cover mechanics to Half-Life.  I recognize that it's a technical limitation and would require a lot of work to fix, and it's not nearly as big of an issue as formations and tactics being removed though, so it's something I can overlook.  Worrying about fuel did become a hassle at times.edit: One thing I forgot to mention is that Homeworld used a weapon system where projectiles/beams were fired and whether they hit or not depended on... well, whether they actually hit or not.  The bullets were physical objects which could be dodged.  Everything in Homeworld 2's combat is based on accuracy percentages, and this is how Homeworld's combat now works due to it being based on HW2's engine.  This isn't game-breaking but it does make the game feel less... I don't know how to describe it... less real?  Less dynamic?  The results of combat are predictable.  [X] always beats [Y] in [Z] scenario.  The real-world effect of this change is often only cosmetic but I think it does detract from the original game's gameplay feel.-----Gearbox has been vaguely promising a patch to solve at least the formation and tactics problem for almost a year now.  Maybe it'll come out eventually, who knows.  It's hard to forgive that they shipped the game in this state.  It's beginning to look like Homeworld Remastered Collection is just the latest in Gearbox's series of recent acquisitions followed by cynical cash-grabs, which began with Duke Nukem Forever and Aliens Colonial Marines.  With all three of these titles, Gearbox did a big song and dance about how they were huge fans of the franchise and "wanted to do right by the fans", then released a broken mess.  At least the had the decency to not add DLC or resource bonus microtransactions.Of the three titles, only Homeworld Remastered Collection was received favorably (mainly by critics and customers who'd never played the original), and it's the only one that's received a follow-up.  You know, it's funny, I don't remember Randy Pitchford sending out any cocky tweets about pre-order numbers for Deserts of Kharak like he did for Homeworld Remastered Collection.  I can't imagine why.

												A true classic, where do I begin...-Gameplay is incredible (especialy in 2) and is very engadging. With alot of variety and stratagy not to mention a very crafty AI that will keep you on your toes.-The story in 1 is one of the best in all of gaming and is a truely moving experience.-The backgrounds and textures are absolutely beautiful and shows just how a remaster should be done.The only thing I can say I did not like was that some of the story missions were occasionaly tedious, but VS CPU mode and a fantastic story more than make up for it. All in all this game is a masterpiece and is well worth $35.

Posted: February 10, 2016
												Homeworld is an RTS in true 3D with a fantastic art style. Visually it looks like a 1970s/1980s sci-fi, like old-school Battle Star Galactica and Star Wars. Check out the artist Chris Foss if you like the visuals in Homeworld - it's very reminiscent of Foss's work. The art stye is also reminiscent of those old Usborne Books of the Future I used to read as kid.Much like a classic book, Homeworld seems timeless. I cannot believe that I was playing this game 16(!) years ago and yet here I am playing it today with gameplay that's still just as good, just as fun as it was so many years ago.I'd gladly pay $40 each for both Homeworld and Homeworld 2, but here you're getting both, remastered for same price. In fact, I only paid $20 since the game was on sale for 50% off.  Great value! Both games have a decent single player campaign, skirmish modes and multiplayer. Even if you have just the smallest desire to play an RTS, check out Homeworld. An old favorite that still holds up.
